And I mean my boy to go to him at\r\nMidsummer,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded, in a tone of decision, tapping his snuff-box\r\nand taking a pinch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll have to pay a swinging half-yearly bill, then, eh, Tulliver?\r\nThe clergymen have highish notions, in general,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Deane, taking\r\nsnuff vigorously, as he always did when wishing to maintain a neutral\r\nposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! do you think the parson\xe2\x80\x99ll teach him to know a good sample o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwheat when he sees it, neighbour Tulliver?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg, who was fond\r\nof his jest, and having retired from business, felt that it was not\r\nonly allowable but becoming in him to take a playful view of things.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you see, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a plan i\xe2\x80\x99 my head about Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver,\r\npausing after that statement and lifting up his glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if I may be allowed to speak, and it\xe2\x80\x99s seldom as I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs\r\nGlegg, with a tone of bitter meaning, \xe2\x80\x9cI should like to know what good\r\nis to come to the boy by bringin\xe2\x80\x99 him up above his fortin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, not looking at Mrs Glegg, but at the male part\r\nof his audience, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see, I\xe2\x80\x99ve made up my mind not to bring Tom up to\r\nmy own business. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had my thoughts about it all along, and I made up\r\nmy mind by what I saw with Garnett and _his_ son. I mean to put him to\r\nsome business as he can go into without capital, and I want to give him\r\nan eddication as he\xe2\x80\x99ll be even wi\xe2\x80\x99 the lawyers and folks, and put me up\r\nto a notion now an\xe2\x80\x99 then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Glegg emitted a long sort of guttural sound with closed lips, that\r\nsmiled in mingled pity and scorn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt \xe2\x80\x99ud be a fine deal better for some people,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, after that\r\nintroductory note, \xe2\x80\x9cif they\xe2\x80\x99d let the lawyers alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he at the head of a grammar school, then, this clergyman, such as\r\nthat at Market Bewley?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Deane.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nothing of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver. \xe2\x80\x9cHe won\xe2\x80\x99t take more than two\r\nor three pupils, and so he\xe2\x80\x99ll have the more time to attend to \xe2\x80\x99em, you\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, and get his eddication done the sooner; they can\xe2\x80\x99t learn much at a\r\ntime when there\xe2\x80\x99s so many of \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d said uncle Pullet, feeling that he\r\nwas getting quite an insight into this difficult matter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he\xe2\x80\x99ll want the more pay, I doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay, a cool hundred a year, that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, with\r\nsome pride at his own spirited course. \xe2\x80\x9cBut then, you know, it\xe2\x80\x99s an\r\ninvestment; Tom\xe2\x80\x99s eddication \xe2\x80\x99ull be so much capital to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, there\xe2\x80\x99s something in that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg. \xe2\x80\x9cWell well, neighbour\r\nTulliver, you may be right, you may be right:\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x98When land is gone and money\xe2\x80\x99s spent,\r\n     Then learning is most excellent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember seeing those two lines wrote on a window at Buxton. But us\r\nthat have got no learning had better keep our money, eh, neighbour\r\nPullet?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr Glegg rubbed his knees, and looked very pleasant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Glegg, I wonder _at_ you,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very unbecoming in\r\na man o\xe2\x80\x99 your age and belongings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s unbecoming, Mrs G.?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg, winking pleasantly at the\r\ncompany. \xe2\x80\x9cMy new blue coat as I\xe2\x80\x99ve got on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pity your weakness, Mr Glegg. I say it\xe2\x80\x99s unbecoming to be making a\r\njoke when you see your own kin going headlongs to ruin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you mean me by that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, considerably nettled, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nneedn\xe2\x80\x99t trouble yourself to fret about me. I can manage my own affairs\r\nwithout troubling other folks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Deane, judiciously introducing a new idea, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy,\r\nnow I come to think of it, somebody said Wakem was going to send _his_\r\nson\xe2\x80\x94the deformed lad\xe2\x80\x94to a clergyman, didn\xe2\x80\x99t they, Susan?\xe2\x80\x9d (appealing to\r\nhis wife).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can give no account of it, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Deane, closing her\r\nlips very tightly again. Mrs Deane was not a woman to take part in a\r\nscene where missiles were flying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, speaking all the more cheerfully, that Mrs\r\nGlegg might see he didn\xe2\x80\x99t mind her, \xe2\x80\x9cif Wakem thinks o\xe2\x80\x99 sending his son\r\nto a clergyman, depend on it I shall make no mistake i\xe2\x80\x99 sending Tom to\r\none. Wakem\xe2\x80\x99s as big a scoundrel as Old Harry ever made, but he knows\r\nthe length of every man\xe2\x80\x99s foot he\xe2\x80\x99s got to deal with. Ay, ay, tell me\r\nwho\xe2\x80\x99s Wakem\xe2\x80\x99s butcher, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you where to get your meat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut lawyer Wakem\xe2\x80\x99s son\xe2\x80\x99s got a hump-back,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, who felt\r\nas if the whole business had a funereal aspect; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s more nat\xe2\x80\x99ral to\r\nsend _him_ to a clergyman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg, interpreting Mrs Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s observation with\r\nerroneous plausibility, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must consider that, neighbour Tulliver;\r\nWakem\xe2\x80\x99s son isn\xe2\x80\x99t likely to follow any business. Wakem \xe2\x80\x99ull make a\r\ngentleman of him, poor fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Glegg,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs G., in a tone which implied that her indignation\r\nwould fizz and ooze a little, though she was determined to keep it\r\ncorked up, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d far better hold your tongue. Mr Tulliver doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nto know your opinion nor mine either. There\xe2\x80\x99s folks in the world as\r\nknow better than everybody else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I should think that\xe2\x80\x99s you, if we\xe2\x80\x99re to trust your own tale,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr Tulliver, beginning to boil up again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, _I_ say nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg, sarcastically. \xe2\x80\x9cMy advice has\r\nnever been asked, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t give it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll be the first time, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the only thing\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re over-ready at giving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been over-ready at lending, then, if I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been over-ready at\r\ngiving,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s folks I\xe2\x80\x99ve lent money to, as perhaps\r\nI shall repent o\xe2\x80\x99 lending money to kin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg, soothingly. But Mr Tulliver was not\r\nto be hindered of his retort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve got a bond for it, I reckon,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand you\xe2\x80\x99ve had your\r\nfive per cent, kin or no kin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSister,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, pleadingly, \xe2\x80\x9cdrink your wine, and let me\r\ngive you some almonds and raisins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBessy, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg, very much with the feeling\r\nof a cur that seizes the opportunity of diverting his bark toward the\r\nman who carries no stick. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s poor work talking o\xe2\x80\x99 almonds and\r\nraisins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLors, sister Glegg, don\xe2\x80\x99t be so quarrelsome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet,\r\nbeginning to cry a little. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may be struck with a fit, getting so\r\nred in the face after dinner, and we are but just out o\xe2\x80\x99 mourning, all\r\nof us,\xe2\x80\x94and all wi\xe2\x80\x99 gowns craped alike and just put by; it\xe2\x80\x99s very bad\r\namong sisters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think it _is_ bad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg. \xe2\x80\x9cThings are come to a\r\nfine pass when one sister invites the other to her house o\xe2\x80\x99 purpose to\r\nquarrel with her and abuse her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoftly, softly, Jane; be reasonable, be reasonable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg.\r\n\r\nBut while he was speaking, Mr Tulliver, who had by no means said enough\r\nto satisfy his anger, burst out again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho wants to quarrel with you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s you as can\xe2\x80\x99t let people\r\nalone, but must be gnawing at \xe2\x80\x99em forever. _I_ should never want to\r\nquarrel with any woman if she kept her place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy place, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg, getting rather more shrill.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s your betters, Mr Tulliver, as are dead and in their grave,\r\ntreated me with a different sort o\xe2\x80\x99 respect to what you do; _though_\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a husband as\xe2\x80\x99ll sit by and see me abused by them as \xe2\x80\x99ud never\r\nha\xe2\x80\x99 had the chance if there hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been them in our family as married\r\nworse than they might ha\xe2\x80\x99 done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you talk o\xe2\x80\x99 that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, \xe2\x80\x9cmy family\xe2\x80\x99s as good as yours,\r\nand better, for it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t got a damned ill-tempered woman in it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg, rising from her chair, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether\r\nyou think it\xe2\x80\x99s a fine thing to sit by and hear me swore at, Mr Glegg;\r\nbut I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to stay a minute longer in this house. You can stay\r\nbehind, and come home with the gig, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll walk home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear heart, dear heart!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg in a melancholy tone, as he\r\nfollowed his wife out of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Tulliver, how could you talk so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, with the tears\r\nin her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, too hot to be damped by any amount of\r\ntears. \xe2\x80\x9cLet her go, and the sooner the better; she won\xe2\x80\x99t be trying to\r\ndomineer over _me_ again in a hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSister Pullet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, helplessly, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think it \xe2\x80\x99ud be\r\nany use for you to go after her and try to pacify her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter not, better not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Deane. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll make it up another\r\nday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, sisters, shall we go and look at the children?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs\r\nTulliver, drying her eyes.\r\n\r\nNo proposition could have been more seasonable. Mr Tulliver felt very\r\nmuch as if the air had been cleared of obtrusive flies now the women\r\nwere out of the room. There were few things he liked better than a chat\r\nwith Mr Deane, whose close application to business allowed the pleasure\r\nvery rarely. Mr Deane, he considered, was the \xe2\x80\x9cknowingest\xe2\x80\x9d man of his\r\nacquaintance, and he had besides a ready causticity of tongue that made\r\nan agreeable supplement to Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s own tendency that way, which\r\nhad remained in rather an inarticulate condition. And now the women\r\nwere gone, they could carry on their serious talk without frivolous\r\ninterruption. They could exchange their views concerning the Duke of\r\nWellington, whose conduct in the Catholic Question had thrown such an\r\nentirely new light on his character; and speak slightingly of his\r\nconduct at the battle of Waterloo, which he would never have won if\r\nthere hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been a great many Englishmen at his back, not to speak of\r\nBlucher and the Prussians, who, as Mr Tulliver had heard from a person\r\nof particular knowledge in that matter, had come up in the very nick of\r\ntime; though here there was a slight dissidence, Mr Deane remarking\r\nthat he was not disposed to give much credit to the Prussians,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nbuild of their vessels, together with the unsatisfactory character of\r\ntransactions in Dantzic beer, inclining him to form rather a low view\r\nof Prussian pluck generally. Rather beaten on this ground, Mr Tulliver\r\nproceeded to express his fears that the country could never again be\r\nwhat it used to be; but Mr Deane, attached to a firm of which the\r\nreturns were on the increase, naturally took a more lively view of the\r\npresent, and had some details to give concerning the state of the\r\nimports, especially in hides and spelter, which soothed Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimagination by throwing into more distant perspective the period when\r\nthe country would become utterly the prey of Papists and Radicals, and\r\nthere would be no more chance for honest men.\r\n\r\nUncle Pullet sat by and listened with twinkling eyes to these high\r\nmatters. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand politics himself,\xe2\x80\x94thought they were a\r\nnatural gift,\xe2\x80\x94but by what he could make out, this Duke of Wellington\r\nwas no better than he should be.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VIII.\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver Shows His Weaker Side\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose sister Glegg should call her money in; it \xe2\x80\x99ud be very awkward\r\nfor you to have to raise five hundred pounds now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver to\r\nher husband that evening, as she took a plaintive review of the day.\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver had lived thirteen years with her husband, yet she\r\nretained in all the freshness of her early married life a facility of\r\nsaying things which drove him in the opposite direction to the one she\r\ndesired. Some minds are wonderful for keeping their bloom in this way,\r\nas a patriarchal goldfish apparently retains to the last its youthful\r\nillusion that it can swim in a straight line beyond the encircling\r\nglass. Mrs Tulliver was an amiable fish of this kind, and after running\r\nher head against the same resisting medium for thirteen years would go\r\nat it again to-day with undulled alacrity.\r\n\r\nThis observation of hers tended directly to convince Mr Tulliver that\r\nit would not be at all awkward for him to raise five hundred pounds;\r\nand when Mrs Tulliver became rather pressing to know _how_ he would\r\nraise it without mortgaging the mill and the house which he had said he\r\nnever _would_ mortgage, since nowadays people were none so ready to\r\nlend money without security, Mr Tulliver, getting warm, declared that\r\nMrs Glegg might do as she liked about calling in her money, he should\r\npay it in whether or not. He was not going to be beholden to his wife\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsisters. When a man had married into a family where there was a whole\r\nlitter of women, he might have plenty to put up with if he chose. But\r\nMr Tulliver did _not_ choose.\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver cried a little in a trickling, quiet way as she put on her\r\nnightcap; but presently sank into a comfortable sleep, lulled by the\r\nthought that she would talk everything over with her sister Pullet\r\nto-morrow, when she was to take the children to Garum Firs to tea. Not\r\nthat she looked forward to any distinct issue from that talk; but it\r\nseemed impossible that past events should be so obstinate as to remain\r\nunmodified when they were complained against.\r\n\r\nHer husband lay awake rather longer, for he too was thinking of a visit\r\nhe would pay on the morrow; and his ideas on the subject were not of so\r\nvague and soothing a kind as those of his amiable partner.\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver, when under the influence of a strong feeling, had a\r\npromptitude in action that may seem inconsistent with that painful\r\nsense of the complicated, puzzling nature of human affairs under which\r\nhis more dispassionate deliberations were conducted; but it is really\r\nnot improbable that there was a direct relation between these\r\napparently contradictory phenomena, since I have observed that for\r\ngetting a strong impression that a skein is tangled there is nothing\r\nlike snatching hastily at a single thread. It was owing to this\r\npromptitude that Mr Tulliver was on horseback soon after dinner the\r\nnext day (he was not dyspeptic) on his way to Basset to see his sister\r\nMoss and her husband. For having made up his mind irrevocably that he\r\nwould pay Mrs Glegg her loan of five hundred pounds, it naturally\r\noccurred to him that he had a promissory note for three hundred pounds\r\nlent to his brother-in-law Moss; and if the said brother-in-law could\r\nmanage to pay in the money within a given time, it would go far to\r\nlessen the fallacious air of inconvenience which Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s spirited\r\nstep might have worn in the eyes of weak people who require to know\r\nprecisely _how_ a thing is to be done before they are strongly\r\nconfident that it will be easy.\r\n\r\nFor Mr Tulliver was in a position neither new nor striking, but, like\r\nother everyday things, sure to have a cumulative effect that will be\r\nfelt in the long run: he was held to be a much more substantial man\r\nthan he really was. And as we are all apt to believe what the world\r\nbelieves about us, it was his habit to think of failure and ruin with\r\nthe same sort of remote pity with which a spare, long-necked man hears\r\nthat his plethoric short-necked neighbour is stricken with apoplexy. He\r\nhad been always used to hear pleasant jokes about his advantages as a\r\nman who worked his own mill, and owned a pretty bit of land; and these\r\njokes naturally kept up his sense that he was a man of considerable\r\nsubstance. They gave a pleasant flavour to his glass on a market-day,\r\nand if it had not been for the recurrence of half-yearly payments, Mr\r\nTulliver would really have forgotten that there was a mortgage of two\r\nthousand pounds on his very desirable freehold. That was not altogether\r\nhis own fault, since one of the thousand pounds was his sister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfortune, which he had to pay on her marriage; and a man who has\r\nneighbours that _will_ go to law with him is not likely to pay off his\r\nmortgages, especially if he enjoys the good opinion of acquaintances\r\nwho want to borrow a hundred pounds on security too lofty to be\r\nrepresented by parchment. Our friend Mr Tulliver had a good-natured\r\nfibre in him, and did not like to give harsh refusals even to his\r\nsister, who had not only come in to the world in that superfluous way\r\ncharacteristic of sisters, creating a necessity for mortgages, but had\r\nquite thrown herself away in marriage, and had crowned her mistakes by\r\nhaving an eighth baby. On this point Mr Tulliver was conscious of being\r\na little weak; but he apologised to himself by saying that poor Gritty\r\nhad been a good-looking wench before she married Moss; he would\r\nsometimes say this even with a slight tremulousness in his voice. But\r\nthis morning he was in a mood more becoming a man of business, and in\r\nthe course of his ride along the Basset lanes, with their deep\r\nruts,\xe2\x80\x94lying so far away from a market-town that the labour of drawing\r\nproduce and manure was enough to take away the best part of the profits\r\non such poor land as that parish was made of,\xe2\x80\x94he got up a due amount of\r\nirritation against Moss as a man without capital, who, if murrain and\r\nblight were abroad, was sure to have his share of them, and who, the\r\nmore you tried to help him out of the mud, would sink the further in.\r\nIt would do him good rather than harm, now, if he were obliged to raise\r\nthis three hundred pounds; it would make him look about him better, and\r\nnot act so foolishly about his wool this year as he did the last; in\r\nfact, Mr Tulliver had been too easy with his brother-in-law, and\r\nbecause he had let the interest run on for two years, Moss was likely\r\nenough to think that he should never be troubled about the principal.\r\nBut Mr Tulliver was determined not to encourage such shuffling people\r\nany longer; and a ride along the Basset lanes was not likely to\r\nenervate a man\xe2\x80\x99s resolution by softening his temper. The deep-trodden\r\nhoof-marks, made in the muddiest days of winter, gave him a shake now\r\nand then which suggested a rash but stimulating snarl at the father of\r\nlawyers, who, whether by means of his hoof or otherwise, had doubtless\r\nsomething to do with this state of the roads; and the abundance of foul\r\nland and neglected fences that met his eye, though they made no part of\r\nhis brother Moss\xe2\x80\x99s farm, strongly contributed to his dissatisfaction\r\nwith that unlucky agriculturist. If this wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Moss\xe2\x80\x99s fallow, it might\r\nhave been; Basset was all alike; it was a beggarly parish, in Mr\r\nTulliver\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, and his opinion was certainly not groundless.\r\nBasset had a poor soil, poor roads, a poor non-resident landlord, a\r\npoor non-resident vicar, and rather less than half a curate, also poor.\r\nIf any one strongly impressed with the power of the human mind to\r\ntriumph over circumstances will contend that the parishioners of Basset\r\nmight nevertheless have been a very superior class of people, I have\r\nnothing to urge against that abstract proposition; I only know that, in\r\npoint of fact, the Basset mind was in strict keeping with its\r\ncircumstances. The muddy lanes, green or clayey, that seemed to the\r\nunaccustomed eye to lead nowhere but into each other, did really lead,\r\nwith patience, to a distant high-road; but there were many feet in\r\nBasset which they led more frequently to a centre of dissipation,\r\nspoken of formerly as the \xe2\x80\x9cMarkis o\xe2\x80\x99 Granby,\xe2\x80\x9d but among intimates as\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDickison\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d A large low room with a sanded floor; a cold scent of\r\ntobacco, modified by undetected beer-dregs; Mr Dickison leaning against\r\nthe door-post with a melancholy pimpled face, looking as irrelevant to\r\nthe daylight as a last night\xe2\x80\x99s guttered candle,\xe2\x80\x94all this may not seem a\r\nvery seductive form of temptation; but the majority of men in Basset\r\nfound it fatally alluring when encountered on their road toward four\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock on a wintry afternoon; and if any wife in Basset wished to\r\nindicate that her husband was not a pleasure-seeking man, she could\r\nhardly do it more emphatically than by saying that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t spend a\r\nshilling at Dickison\xe2\x80\x99s from one Whitsuntide to another. Mrs Moss had\r\nsaid so of _her_ husband more than once, when her brother was in a mood\r\nto find fault with him, as he certainly was to-day. And nothing could\r\nbe less pacifying to Mr Tulliver than the behaviour of the farmyard\r\ngate, which he no sooner attempted to push open with his riding-stick\r\nthan it acted as gates without the upper hinge are known to do, to the\r\nperil of shins, whether equine or human. He was about to get down and\r\nlead his horse through the damp dirt of the hollow farmyard, shadowed\r\ndrearily by the large half-timbered buildings, up to the long line of\r\ntumble-down dwelling-houses standing on a raised causeway; but the\r\ntimely appearance of a cowboy saved him that frustration of a plan he\r\nhad determined on,\xe2\x80\x94namely, not to get down from his horse during this\r\nvisit. If a man means to be hard, let him keep in his saddle and speak\r\nfrom that height, above the level of pleading eyes, and with the\r\ncommand of a distant horizon. Mrs Moss heard the sound of the horse\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeet, and, when her brother rode up, was already outside the kitchen\r\ndoor, with a half-weary smile on her face, and a black-eyed baby in her\r\narms. Mrs Moss\xe2\x80\x99s face bore a faded resemblance to her brother\xe2\x80\x99s; baby\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlittle fat hand, pressed against her cheek, seemed to show more\r\nstrikingly that the cheek was faded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in an affectionate tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t look for you to-day. How do you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, pretty well, Mrs Moss, pretty well,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the brother, with\r\ncool deliberation, as if it were rather too forward of her to ask that\r\nquestion. She knew at once that her brother was not in a good humour;\r\nhe never called her Mrs Moss except when he was angry, and when they\r\nwere in company. But she thought it was in the order of nature that\r\npeople who were poorly off should be snubbed. Mrs Moss did not take her\r\nstand on the equality of the human race; she was a patient, prolific,\r\nloving-hearted woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour husband isn\xe2\x80\x99t in the house, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d added Mr Tulliver after a\r\ngrave pause, during which four children had run out, like chickens\r\nwhose mother has been suddenly in eclipse behind the hen-coop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Moss, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he\xe2\x80\x99s only in the potato-field yonders.\r\nGeorgy, run to the Far Close in a minute, and tell father your uncle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncome. You\xe2\x80\x99ll get down, brother, won\xe2\x80\x99t you, and take something?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; I can\xe2\x80\x99t get down. I must be going home again directly,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr Tulliver, looking at the distance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how\xe2\x80\x99s Mrs Tulliver and the children?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Moss, humbly, not\r\ndaring to press her invitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, pretty well. Tom\xe2\x80\x99s going to a new school at Midsummer,\xe2\x80\x94a deal of\r\nexpense to me. It\xe2\x80\x99s bad work for me, lying out o\xe2\x80\x99 my money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you\xe2\x80\x99d be so good as let the children come and see their cousins\r\nsome day. My little uns want to see their cousin Maggie so as never\r\nwas. And me her godmother, and so fond of her; there\xe2\x80\x99s nobody \xe2\x80\x99ud make\r\na bigger fuss with her, according to what they\xe2\x80\x99ve got. And I know she\r\nlikes to come, for she\xe2\x80\x99s a loving child, and how quick and clever she\r\nis, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf Mrs Moss had been one of the most astute women in the world, instead\r\nof being one of the simplest, she could have thought of nothing more\r\nlikely to propitiate her brother than this praise of Maggie. He seldom\r\nfound any one volunteering praise of \xe2\x80\x9cthe little wench\xe2\x80\x9d; it was usually\r\nleft entirely to himself to insist on her merits. But Maggie always\r\nappeared in the most amiable light at her aunt Moss\xe2\x80\x99s; it was her\r\nAlsatia, where she was out of the reach of law,\xe2\x80\x94if she upset anything,\r\ndirtied her shoes, or tore her frock, these things were matters of\r\ncourse at her aunt Moss\xe2\x80\x99s. In spite of himself, Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s eyes got\r\nmilder, and he did not look away from his sister as he said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy; she\xe2\x80\x99s fonder o\xe2\x80\x99 you than o\xe2\x80\x99 the other aunts, I think. She takes\r\nafter our family: not a bit of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s in her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoss says she\xe2\x80\x99s just like what I used to be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Moss, \xe2\x80\x9cthough I\r\nwas never so quick and fond o\xe2\x80\x99 the books. But I think my Lizzy\xe2\x80\x99s like\r\nher; _she\xe2\x80\x99s_ sharp. Come here, Lizzy, my dear, and let your uncle see\r\nyou; he hardly knows you, you grow so fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLizzy, a black-eyed child of seven, looked very shy when her mother\r\ndrew her forward, for the small Mosses were much in awe of their uncle\r\nfrom Dorlcote Mill. She was inferior enough to Maggie in fire and\r\nstrength of expression to make the resemblance between the two entirely\r\nflattering to Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s fatherly love.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, they\xe2\x80\x99re a bit alike,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking kindly at the little figure\r\nin the soiled pinafore. \xe2\x80\x9cThey both take after our mother. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\nenough o\xe2\x80\x99 gells, Gritty,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, in a tone half compassionate, half\r\nreproachful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour of \xe2\x80\x99em, bless \xe2\x80\x99em!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Moss, with a sigh, stroking Lizzy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhair on each side of her forehead; \xe2\x80\x9cas many as there\xe2\x80\x99s boys. They\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot a brother apiece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but they must turn out and fend for themselves,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver,\r\nfeeling that his severity was relaxing and trying to brace it by\r\nthrowing out a wholesome hint \xe2\x80\x9cThey mustn\xe2\x80\x99t look to hanging on their\r\nbrothers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but I hope their brothers \xe2\x80\x99ull love the poor things, and remember\r\nthey came o\xe2\x80\x99 one father and mother; the lads \xe2\x80\x99ull never be the poorer\r\nfor that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Moss, flashing out with hurried timidity, like a\r\nhalf-smothered fire.\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver gave his horse a little stroke on the flank, then checked\r\nit, and said angrily, \xe2\x80\x9cStand still with you!\xe2\x80\x9d much to the astonishment\r\nof that innocent animal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the more there is of \xe2\x80\x99em, the more they must love one another,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nMrs Moss went on, looking at her children with a didactic purpose. But\r\nshe turned toward her brother again to say, \xe2\x80\x9cNot but what I hope your\r\nboy \xe2\x80\x99ull allays be good to his sister, though there\xe2\x80\x99s but two of \xe2\x80\x99em,\r\nlike you and me, brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe arrow went straight to Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s heart. He had not a rapid\r\nimagination, but the thought of Maggie was very near to him, and he was\r\nnot long in seeing his relation to his own sister side by side with\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s relation to Maggie. Would the little wench ever be poorly off,\r\nand Tom rather hard upon her?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay, Gritty,\xe2\x80\x9d said the miller, with a new softness in his tone;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99ve allays done what I could for you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, as if\r\nvindicating himself from a reproach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not denying that, brother, and I\xe2\x80\x99m noways ungrateful,\xe2\x80\x9d said poor\r\nMrs Moss, too fagged by toil and children to have strength left for any\r\npride. \xe2\x80\x9cBut here\xe2\x80\x99s the father. What a while you\xe2\x80\x99ve been, Moss!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile, do you call it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Moss, feeling out of breath and\r\ninjured. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been running all the way. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you \xe2\x80\x99light, Mr\r\nTulliver?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll just get down and have a bit o\xe2\x80\x99 talk with you in the\r\ngarden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, thinking that he should be more likely to\r\nshow a due spirit of resolve if his sister were not present.\r\n\r\nHe got down, and passed with Mr Moss into the garden, toward an old\r\nyew-tree arbour, while his sister stood tapping her baby on the back\r\nand looking wistfully after them.\r\n\r\nTheir entrance into the yew-tree arbour surprised several fowls that\r\nwere recreating themselves by scratching deep holes in the dusty\r\nground, and at once took flight with much pother and cackling. Mr\r\nTulliver sat down on the bench, and tapping the ground curiously here\r\nand there with his stick, as if he suspected some hollowness, opened\r\nthe conversation by observing, with something like a snarl in his\r\ntone,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got wheat again in that Corner Close, I see; and never a\r\nbit o\xe2\x80\x99 dressing on it. You\xe2\x80\x99ll do no good with it this year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Moss, who, when he married Miss Tulliver, had been regarded as the\r\nbuck of Basset, now wore a beard nearly a week old, and had the\r\ndepressed, unexpectant air of a machine-horse. He answered in a\r\npatient-grumbling tone, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, poor farmers like me must do as they can;\r\nthey must leave it to them as have got money to play with, to put half\r\nas much into the ground as they mean to get out of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know who should have money to play with, if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t them as\r\ncan borrow money without paying interest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, who wished\r\nto get into a slight quarrel; it was the most natural and easy\r\nintroduction to calling in money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know I\xe2\x80\x99m behind with the interest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Moss, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I was so\r\nunlucky wi\xe2\x80\x99 the wool last year; and what with the Missis being laid up\r\nso, things have gone awk\xe2\x80\x99arder nor usual.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d snarled Mr Tulliver, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s folks as things \xe2\x80\x99ull allays go\r\nawk\xe2\x80\x99ard with; empty sacks \xe2\x80\x99ull never stand upright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what fault you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to find wi\xe2\x80\x99 me, Mr Tulliver,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mr Moss, deprecatingly; \xe2\x80\x9cI know there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a day-labourer works\r\nharder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use o\xe2\x80\x99 that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, sharply, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen a man\r\nmarries, and\xe2\x80\x99s got no capital to work his farm but his wife\xe2\x80\x99s bit o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nfortin? I was against it from the first; but you\xe2\x80\x99d neither of you\r\nlisten to me. And I can\xe2\x80\x99t lie out o\xe2\x80\x99 my money any longer, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\nto pay five hundred o\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Glegg\xe2\x80\x99s, and there\xe2\x80\x99ll be Tom an expense to\r\nme. I should find myself short, even saying I\xe2\x80\x99d got back all as is my\r\nown. You must look about and see how you can pay me the three hundred\r\npound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if that\xe2\x80\x99s what you mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Moss, looking blankly before\r\nhim, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99d better be sold up, and ha\xe2\x80\x99 done with it; I must part wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nevery head o\xe2\x80\x99 stock I\xe2\x80\x99ve got, to pay you and the landlord too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor relations are undeniably irritating,\xe2\x80\x94their existence is so\r\nentirely uncalled for on our part, and they are almost always very\r\nfaulty people. Mr Tulliver had succeeded in getting quite as much\r\nirritated with Mr Moss as he had desired, and he was able to say\r\nangrily, rising from his seat,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you must do as you can. _I_ can\xe2\x80\x99t find money for everybody else\r\nas well as myself. I must look to my own business and my own family. I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t lie out o\xe2\x80\x99 my money any longer. You must raise it as quick as you\r\ncan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver walked abruptly out of the arbour as he uttered the last\r\nsentence, and, without looking round at Mr Moss, went on to the kitchen\r\ndoor, where the eldest boy was holding his horse, and his sister was\r\nwaiting in a state of wondering alarm, which was not without its\r\nalleviations, for baby was making pleasant gurgling sounds, and\r\nperforming a great deal of finger practice on the faded face. Mrs Moss\r\nhad eight children, but could never overcome her regret that the twins\r\nhad not lived. Mr Moss thought their removal was not without its\r\nconsolations. \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you come in, brother?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking anxiously\r\nat her husband, who was walking slowly up, while Mr Tulliver had his\r\nfoot already in the stirrup.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; good-by,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning his horse\xe2\x80\x99s head, and riding away.\r\n\r\nNo man could feel more resolute till he got outside the yard gate, and\r\na little way along the deep-rutted lane; but before he reached the next\r\nturning, which would take him out of sight of the dilapidated\r\nfarm-buildings, he appeared to be smitten by some sudden thought. He\r\nchecked his horse, and made it stand still in the same spot for two or\r\nthree minutes, during which he turned his head from side to side in a\r\nmelancholy way, as if he were looking at some painful object on more\r\nsides than one. Evidently, after his fit of promptitude, Mr Tulliver\r\nwas relapsing into the sense that this is a puzzling world. He turned\r\nhis horse, and rode slowly back, giving vent to the climax of feeling\r\nwhich had determined this movement by saying aloud, as he struck his\r\nhorse, \xe2\x80\x9cPoor little wench! she\xe2\x80\x99ll have nobody but Tom, belike, when I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ngone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s return into the yard was descried by several young\r\nMosses, who immediately ran in with the exciting news to their mother,\r\nso that Mrs Moss was again on the door-step when her brother rode up.\r\nShe had been crying, but was rocking baby to sleep in her arms now, and\r\nmade no ostentatious show of sorrow as her brother looked at her, but\r\nmerely said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe father\xe2\x80\x99s gone to the field, again, if you want him, brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Gritty, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, in a gentle tone. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nfret,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll make a shift without the money a bit, only you\r\nmust be as clever and contriving as you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Moss\xe2\x80\x99s tears came again at this unexpected kindness, and she could\r\nsay nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come!\xe2\x80\x94the little wench shall come and see you. I\xe2\x80\x99ll bring her\r\nand Tom some day before he goes to school. You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t fret. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nallays be a good brother to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you for that word, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Moss, drying her tears;\r\nthen turning to Lizzy, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cRun now, and fetch the coloured egg\r\nfor cousin Maggie.\xe2\x80\x9d Lizzy ran in, and quickly reappeared with a small\r\npaper parcel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s boiled hard, brother, and coloured with thrums, very pretty; it\r\nwas done o\xe2\x80\x99 purpose for Maggie. Will you please to carry it in your\r\npocket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, putting it carefully in his side pocket.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd so the respectable miller returned along the Basset lanes rather\r\nmore puzzled than before as to ways and means, but still with the sense\r\nof a danger escaped. It had come across his mind that if he were hard\r\nupon his sister, it might somehow tend to make Tom hard upon Maggie at\r\nsome distant day, when her father was no longer there to take her part;\r\nfor simple people, like our friend Mr Tulliver, are apt to clothe\r\nunimpeachable feelings in erroneous ideas, and this was his confused\r\nway of explaining to himself that his love and anxiety for \xe2\x80\x9cthe little\r\nwench\xe2\x80\x9d had given him a new sensibility toward his sister.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IX.\r\n\r\nTo Garum Firs\r\n\r\nWhile the possible troubles of Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s future were occupying her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s mind, she herself was tasting only the bitterness of the\r\npresent. Childhood has no forebodings; but then, it is soothed by no\r\nmemories of outlived sorrow.\r\n\r\nThe fact was, the day had begun ill with Maggie. The pleasure of having\r\nLucy to look at, and the prospect of the afternoon visit to Garum Firs,\r\nwhere she would hear uncle Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s musical box, had been marred as\r\nearly as eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock by the advent of the hair-dresser from St\r\nOgg\xe2\x80\x99s, who had spoken in the severest terms of the condition in which\r\nhe had found her hair, holding up one jagged lock after another and\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x9cSee here! tut, tut, tut!\xe2\x80\x9d in a tone of mingled disgust and\r\npity, which to Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s imagination was equivalent to the strongest\r\nexpression of public opinion. Mr Rappit, the hair-dresser, with his\r\nwell-anointed coronal locks tending wavily upward, like the simulated\r\npyramid of flame on a monumental urn, seemed to her at that moment the\r\nmost formidable of her contemporaries, into whose street at St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshe would carefully refrain from entering through the rest of her life.\r\n\r\nMoreover, the preparation for a visit being always a serious affair in\r\nthe Dodson family, Martha was enjoined to have Mrs Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s room\r\nready an hour earlier than usual, that the laying out of the best\r\nclothes might not be deferred till the last moment, as was sometimes\r\nthe case in families of lax views, where the ribbon-strings were never\r\nrolled up, where there was little or no wrapping in silver paper, and\r\nwhere the sense that the Sunday clothes could be got at quite easily\r\nproduced no shock to the mind. Already, at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Mrs Tulliver\r\nhad on her visiting costume, with a protective apparatus of brown\r\nholland, as if she had been a piece of satin furniture in danger of\r\nflies; Maggie was frowning and twisting her shoulders, that she might\r\nif possible shrink away from the prickliest of tuckers, while her\r\nmother was remonstrating, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, Maggie, my dear; don\xe2\x80\x99t make yourself\r\nso ugly!\xe2\x80\x9d and Tom\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks were looking particularly brilliant as a\r\nrelief to his best blue suit, which he wore with becoming calmness,\r\nhaving, after a little wrangling, effected what was always the one\r\npoint of interest to him in his toilet: he had transferred all the\r\ncontents of his everyday pockets to those actually in wear.\r\n\r\nAs for Lucy, she was just as pretty and neat as she had been yesterday;\r\nno accidents ever happened to her clothes, and she was never\r\nuncomfortable in them, so that she looked with wondering pity at\r\nMaggie, pouting and writhing under the exasperating tucker. Maggie\r\nwould certainly have torn it off, if she had not been checked by the\r\nremembrance of her recent humiliation about her hair; as it was, she\r\nconfined herself to fretting and twisting, and behaving peevishly about\r\nthe card-houses which they were allowed to build till dinner, as a\r\nsuitable amusement for boys and girls in their best clothes. Tom could\r\nbuild perfect pyramids of houses; but Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s would never bear the\r\nlaying on the roof. It was always so with the things that Maggie made;\r\nand Tom had deduced the conclusion that no girls could ever make\r\nanything. But it happened that Lucy proved wonderfully clever at\r\nbuilding; she handled the cards so lightly, and moved so gently, that\r\nTom condescended to admire her houses as well as his own, the more\r\nreadily because she had asked him to teach her. Maggie, too, would have\r\nadmired Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s houses, and would have given up her own unsuccessful\r\nbuilding to contemplate them, without ill temper, if her tucker had not\r\nmade her peevish, and if Tom had not inconsiderately laughed when her\r\nhouses fell, and told her she was \xe2\x80\x9ca stupid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t laugh at me, Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d she burst out angrily; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not a stupid. I\r\nknow a great many things you don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I dare say, Miss Spitfire! I\xe2\x80\x99d never be such a cross thing as you,\r\nmaking faces like that. Lucy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do so. I like Lucy better than\r\nyou; _I_ wish Lucy was _my_ sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it\xe2\x80\x99s very wicked and cruel of you to wish so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie,\r\nstarting up hurriedly from her place on the floor, and upsetting Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwonderful pagoda. She really did not mean it, but the circumstantial\r\nevidence was against her, and Tom turned white with anger, but said\r\nnothing; he would have struck her, only he knew it was cowardly to\r\nstrike a girl, and Tom Tulliver was quite determined he would never do\r\nanything cowardly.\r\n\r\nMaggie stood in dismay and terror, while Tom got up from the floor and\r\nwalked away, pale, from the scattered ruins of his pagoda, and Lucy\r\nlooked on mutely, like a kitten pausing from its lapping.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, at last, going half-way toward him, \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmean to knock it down, indeed, indeed I didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom took no notice of her, but took, instead, two or three hard peas\r\nout of his pocket, and shot them with his thumbnail against the window,\r\nvaguely at first, but presently with the distinct aim of hitting a\r\nsuperannuated blue-bottle which was exposing its imbecility in the\r\nspring sunshine, clearly against the views of Nature, who had provided\r\nTom and the peas for the speedy destruction of this weak individual.\r\n\r\nThus the morning had been made heavy to Maggie, and Tom\xe2\x80\x99s persistent\r\ncoldness to her all through their walk spoiled the fresh air and\r\nsunshine for her. He called Lucy to look at the half-built bird\xe2\x80\x99s nest\r\nwithout caring to show it Maggie, and peeled a willow switch for Lucy\r\nand himself, without offering one to Maggie. Lucy had said, \xe2\x80\x9cMaggie,\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t _you_ like one?\xe2\x80\x9d but Tom was deaf.\r\n\r\nStill, the sight of the peacock opportunely spreading his tail on the\r\nstackyard wall, just as they reached Garum Firs, was enough to divert\r\nthe mind temporarily from personal grievances. And this was only the\r\nbeginning of beautiful sights at Garum Firs. All the farmyard life was\r\nwonderful there,\xe2\x80\x94bantams, speckled and top-knotted; Friesland hens,\r\nwith their feathers all turned the wrong way; Guinea-fowls that flew\r\nand screamed and dropped their pretty spotted feathers; pouter-pigeons\r\nand a tame magpie; nay, a goat, and a wonderful brindled dog, half\r\nmastiff, half bull-dog, as large as a lion. Then there were white\r\nrailings and white gates all about, and glittering weathercocks of\r\nvarious design, and garden-walks paved with pebbles in beautiful\r\npatterns,\xe2\x80\x94nothing was quite common at Garum Firs; and Tom thought that\r\nthe unusual size of the toads there was simply due to the general\r\nunusualness which characterised uncle Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s possessions as a\r\ngentleman farmer. Toads who paid rent were naturally leaner. As for the\r\nhouse, it was not less remarkable; it had a receding centre, and two\r\nwings with battlemented turrets, and was covered with glittering white\r\nstucco.\r\n\r\nUncle Pullet had seen the expected party approaching from the window,\r\nand made haste to unbar and unchain the front door, kept always in this\r\nfortified condition from fear of tramps, who might be supposed to know\r\nof the glass case of stuffed birds in the hall, and to contemplate\r\nrushing in and carrying it away on their heads. Aunt Pullet, too,\r\nappeared at the doorway, and as soon as her sister was within hearing\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cStop the children, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake! Bessy; don\xe2\x80\x99t let \xe2\x80\x99em come up\r\nthe door-steps; Sally\xe2\x80\x99s bringing the old mat and the duster, to rub\r\ntheir shoes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s front-door mats were by no means intended to wipe shoes\r\non; the very scraper had a deputy to do its dirty work. Tom rebelled\r\nparticularly against this shoewiping, which he always considered in the\r\nlight of an indignity to his sex. He felt it as the beginning of the\r\ndisagreeables incident to a visit at aunt Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s, where he had once\r\nbeen compelled to sit with towels wrapped round his boots; a fact which\r\nmay serve to correct the too hasty conclusion that a visit to Garum\r\nFirs must have been a great treat to a young gentleman fond of\r\nanimals,\xe2\x80\x94fond, that is, of throwing stones at them.\r\n\r\nThe next disagreeable was confined to his feminine companions; it was\r\nthe mounting of the polished oak stairs, which had very handsome\r\ncarpets rolled up and laid by in a spare bedroom, so that the ascent of\r\nthese glossy steps might have served, in barbarous times, as a trial by\r\nordeal from which none but the most spotless virtue could have come off\r\nwith unbroken limbs. Sophy\xe2\x80\x99s weakness about these polished stairs was\r\nalways a subject of bitter remonstrance on Mrs Glegg\xe2\x80\x99s part; but Mrs\r\nTulliver ventured on no comment, only thinking to herself it was a\r\nmercy when she and the children were safe on the landing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs Gray has sent home my new bonnet, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, in a\r\npathetic tone, as Mrs Tulliver adjusted her cap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas she, sister?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, with an air of much interest.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how do you like it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s apt to make a mess with clothes, taking \xe2\x80\x99em out and putting \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nin again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, drawing a bunch of keys from her pocket and\r\nlooking at them earnestly, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it \xe2\x80\x99ud be a pity for you to go away\r\nwithout seeing it. There\xe2\x80\x99s no knowing what may happen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Pullet shook her head slowly at this last serious consideration,\r\nwhich determined her to single out a particular key.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid it\xe2\x80\x99ll be troublesome to you getting it out, sister,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMrs Tulliver; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I _should_ like to see what sort of a crown she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmade you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Pullet rose with a melancholy air and unlocked one wing of a very\r\nbright wardrobe, where you may have hastily supposed she would find a\r\nnew bonnet. Not at all. Such a supposition could only have arisen from\r\na too superficial acquaintance with the habits of the Dodson family. In\r\nthis wardrobe Mrs Pullet was seeking something small enough to be\r\nhidden among layers of linen,\xe2\x80\x94it was a door-key.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must come with me into the best room,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the children come too, sister?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mrs Tulliver, who saw\r\nthat Maggie and Lucy were looking rather eager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunt Pullet, reflectively, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99ll perhaps be safer for \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nto come; they\xe2\x80\x99ll be touching something if we leave \xe2\x80\x99em behind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo they went in procession along the bright and slippery corridor,\r\ndimly lighted by the semi-lunar top of the window which rose above the\r\nclosed shutter; it was really quite solemn. Aunt Pullet paused and\r\nunlocked a door which opened on something still more solemn than the\r\npassage,\xe2\x80\x94a darkened room, in which the outer light, entering feebly,\r\nshowed what looked like the corpses of furniture in white shrouds.\r\nEverything that was not shrouded stood with its legs upward. Lucy laid\r\nhold of Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s frock, and Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s heart beat rapidly.\r\n\r\nAunt Pullet half-opened the shutter and then unlocked the wardrobe,\r\nwith a melancholy deliberateness which was quite in keeping with the\r\nfunereal solemnity of the scene. The delicious scent of rose-leaves\r\nthat issued from the wardrobe made the process of taking out sheet\r\nafter sheet of silver paper quite pleasant to assist at, though the\r\nsight of the bonnet at last was an anticlimax to Maggie, who would have\r\npreferred something more strikingly preternatural. But few things could\r\nhave been more impressive to Mrs Tulliver. She looked all round it in\r\nsilence for some moments, and then said emphatically, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, sister,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll never speak against the full crowns again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a great concession, and Mrs Pullet felt it; she felt something\r\nwas due to it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d like to see it on, sister?\xe2\x80\x9d she said sadly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll open the\r\nshutter a bit further.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t mind taking off your cap, sister,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs\r\nTulliver.\r\n\r\nMrs Pullet took off her cap, displaying the brown silk scalp with a\r\njutting promontory of curls which was common to the more mature and\r\njudicious women of those times, and placing the bonnet on her head,\r\nturned slowly round, like a draper\xe2\x80\x99s lay-figure, that Mrs Tulliver\r\nmight miss no point of view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve sometimes thought there\xe2\x80\x99s a loop too much o\xe2\x80\x99 ribbon on this left\r\nside, sister; what do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet.\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver looked earnestly at the point indicated, and turned her\r\nhead on one side. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s best as it is; if you meddled\r\nwith it, sister, you might repent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunt Pullet, taking off the bonnet and looking at\r\nit contemplatively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much might she charge you for that bonnet, sister?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs\r\nTulliver, whose mind was actively engaged on the possibility of getting\r\na humble imitation of this _chef-d\xe2\x80\x99\xc5\x93uvre_ made from a piece of silk she\r\nhad at home.\r\n\r\nMrs Pullet screwed up her mouth and shook her head, and then whispered,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPullet pays for it; he said I was to have the best bonnet at Garum\r\nChurch, let the next best be whose it would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe began slowly to adjust the trimmings, in preparation for returning\r\nit to its place in the wardrobe, and her thoughts seemed to have taken\r\na melancholy turn, for she shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d she said at last, \xe2\x80\x9cI may never wear it twice, sister; who knows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk o\xe2\x80\x99 that sister,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mrs Tulliver. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll have\r\nyour health this summer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! but there may come a death in the family, as there did soon after\r\nI had my green satin bonnet. Cousin Abbott may go, and we can\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 wearing crape less nor half a year for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat _would_ be unlucky,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, entering thoroughly into\r\nthe possibility of an inopportune decease. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s never so much\r\npleasure i\xe2\x80\x99 wearing a bonnet the second year, especially when the\r\ncrowns are so chancy,\xe2\x80\x94never two summers alike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it\xe2\x80\x99s the way i\xe2\x80\x99 this world,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, returning the bonnet\r\nto the wardrobe and locking it up. She maintained a silence\r\ncharacterised by head-shaking, until they had all issued from the\r\nsolemn chamber and were in her own room again. Then, beginning to cry,\r\nshe said, \xe2\x80\x9cSister, if you should never see that bonnet again till I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ndead and gone, you\xe2\x80\x99ll remember I showed it you this day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver felt that she ought to be affected, but she was a woman of\r\nsparse tears, stout and healthy; she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t cry so much as her sister\r\nPullet did, and had often felt her deficiency at funerals. Her effort\r\nto bring tears into her eyes issued in an odd contraction of her face.\r\nMaggie, looking on attentively, felt that there was some painful\r\nmystery about her aunt\xe2\x80\x99s bonnet which she was considered too young to\r\nunderstand; indignantly conscious, all the while, that she could have\r\nunderstood that, as well as everything else, if she had been taken into\r\nconfidence.\r\n\r\nWhen they went down, uncle Pullet observed, with some acumen, that he\r\nreckoned the missis had been showing her bonnet,\xe2\x80\x94that was what had made\r\nthem so long upstairs. With Tom the interval had seemed still longer,\r\nfor he had been seated in irksome constraint on the edge of a sofa\r\ndirectly opposite his uncle Pullet, who regarded him with twinkling\r\ngray eyes, and occasionally addressed him as \xe2\x80\x9cYoung sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, young sir, what do you learn at school?\xe2\x80\x9d was a standing question\r\nwith uncle Pullet; whereupon Tom always looked sheepish, rubbed his\r\nhands across his face, and answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d It was altogether\r\nso embarrassing to be seated _t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate_ with uncle Pullet, that Tom\r\ncould not even look at the prints on the walls, or the flycages, or the\r\nwonderful flower-pots; he saw nothing but his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s gaiters. Not that\r\nTom was in awe of his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s mental superiority; indeed, he had made\r\nup his mind that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to be a gentleman farmer, because he\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like to be such a thin-legged, silly fellow as his uncle\r\nPullet,\xe2\x80\x94a molly-coddle, in fact. A boy\xe2\x80\x99s sheepishness is by no means a\r\nsign of overmastering reverence; and while you are making encouraging\r\nadvances to him under the idea that he is overwhelmed by a sense of\r\nyour age and wisdom, ten to one he is thinking you extremely queer. The\r\nonly consolation I can suggest to you is, that the Greek boys probably\r\nthought the same of Aristotle. It is only when you have mastered a\r\nrestive horse, or thrashed a drayman, or have got a gun in your hand,\r\nthat these shy juniors feel you to be a truly admirable and enviable\r\ncharacter. At least, I am quite sure of Tom Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s sentiments on\r\nthese points. In very tender years, when he still wore a lace border\r\nunder his outdoor cap, he was often observed peeping through the bars\r\nof a gate and making minatory gestures with his small forefinger while\r\nhe scolded the sheep with an inarticulate burr, intended to strike\r\nterror into their astonished minds; indicating thus early that desire\r\nfor mastery over the inferior animals, wild and domestic, including\r\ncockchafers, neighbours\xe2\x80\x99 dogs, and small sisters, which in all ages has\r\nbeen an attribute of so much promise for the fortunes of our race. Now,\r\nMr Pullet never rode anything taller than a low pony, and was the least\r\npredatory of men, considering firearms dangerous, as apt to go off of\r\nthemselves by nobody\xe2\x80\x99s particular desire. So that Tom was not without\r\nstrong reasons when, in confidential talk with a chum, he had described\r\nuncle Pullet as a nincompoop, taking care at the same time to observe\r\nthat he was a very \xe2\x80\x9crich fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe only alleviating circumstance in a _t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate_ with uncle Pullet\r\nwas that he kept a variety of lozenges and peppermint-drops about his\r\nperson, and when at a loss for conversation, he filled up the void by\r\nproposing a mutual solace of this kind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like peppermints, young sir?\xe2\x80\x9d required only a tacit answer when\r\nit was accompanied by a presentation of the article in question.\r\n\r\nThe appearance of the little girls suggested to uncle Pullet the\r\nfurther solace of small sweet-cakes, of which he also kept a stock\r\nunder lock and key for his own private eating on wet days; but the\r\nthree children had no sooner got the tempting delicacy between their\r\nfingers, than aunt Pullet desired them to abstain from eating it till\r\nthe tray and the plates came, since with those crisp cakes they would\r\nmake the floor \xe2\x80\x9call over\xe2\x80\x9d crumbs. Lucy didn\xe2\x80\x99t mind that much, for the\r\ncake was so pretty, she thought it was rather a pity to eat it; but\r\nTom, watching his opportunity while the elders were talking, hastily\r\nstowed it in his mouth at two bites, and chewed it furtively. As for\r\nMaggie, becoming fascinated, as usual, by a print of Ulysses and\r\nNausicaa, which uncle Pullet had bought as a \xe2\x80\x9cpretty Scripture thing,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe presently let fall her cake, and in an unlucky movement crushed it\r\nbeneath her foot,\xe2\x80\x94a source of so much agitation to aunt Pullet and\r\nconscious disgrace to Maggie, that she began to despair of hearing the\r\nmusical snuff-box to-day, till, after some reflection, it occurred to\r\nher that Lucy was in high favour enough to venture on asking for a\r\ntune. So she whispered to Lucy; and Lucy, who always did what she was\r\ndesired to do, went up quietly to her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s knee, and blushing all\r\nover her neck while she fingered her necklace, said, \xe2\x80\x9cWill you please\r\nplay us a tune, uncle?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucy thought it was by reason of some exceptional talent in uncle\r\nPullet that the snuff-box played such beautiful tunes, and indeed the\r\nthing was viewed in that light by the majority of his neighbours in\r\nGarum. Mr Pullet had _bought_ the box, to begin with, and he understood\r\nwinding it up, and knew which tune it was going to play beforehand;\r\naltogether the possession of this unique \xe2\x80\x9cpiece of music\xe2\x80\x9d was a proof\r\nthat Mr Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s character was not of that entire nullity which might\r\notherwise have been attributed to it. But uncle Pullet, when entreated\r\nto exhibit his accomplishment, never depreciated it by a too ready\r\nconsent. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see about it,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer he always gave, carefully\r\nabstaining from any sign of compliance till a suitable number of\r\nminutes had passed. Uncle Pullet had a programme for all great social\r\noccasions, and in this way fenced himself in from much painful\r\nconfusion and perplexing freedom of will.\r\n\r\nPerhaps the suspense did heighten Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s enjoyment when the fairy\r\ntune began; for the first time she quite forgot that she had a load on\r\nher mind, that Tom was angry with her; and by the time \xe2\x80\x9cHush, ye pretty\r\nwarbling choir,\xe2\x80\x9d had been played, her face wore that bright look of\r\nhappiness, while she sat immovable with her hands clasped, which\r\nsometimes comforted her mother with the sense that Maggie could look\r\npretty now and then, in spite of her brown skin. But when the magic\r\nmusic ceased, she jumped up, and running toward Tom, put her arm round\r\nhis neck and said, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Tom, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it pretty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLest you should think it showed a revolting insensibility in Tom that\r\nhe felt any new anger toward Maggie for this uncalled-for and, to him,\r\ninexplicable caress, I must tell you that he had his glass of cowslip\r\nwine in his hand, and that she jerked him so as to make him spill half\r\nof it. He must have been an extreme milksop not to say angrily, \xe2\x80\x9cLook\r\nthere, now!\xe2\x80\x9d especially when his resentment was sanctioned, as it was,\r\nby general disapprobation of Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you sit still, Maggie?\xe2\x80\x9d her mother said peevishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle gells mustn\xe2\x80\x99t come to see me if they behave in that way,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\naunt Pullet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you\xe2\x80\x99re too rough, little miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said uncle Pullet.\r\n\r\nPoor Maggie sat down again, with the music all chased out of her soul,\r\nand the seven small demons all in again.\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver, foreseeing nothing but misbehaviour while the children\r\nremained indoors, took an early opportunity of suggesting that, now\r\nthey were rested after their walk, they might go and play out of doors;\r\nand aunt Pullet gave permission, only enjoining them not to go off the\r\npaved walks in the garden, and if they wanted to see the poultry fed,\r\nto view them from a distance on the horse-block; a restriction which\r\nhad been imposed ever since Tom had been found guilty of running after\r\nthe peacock, with an illusory idea that fright would make one of its\r\nfeathers drop off.\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts had been temporarily diverted from the quarrel\r\nwith Mrs Glegg by millinery and maternal cares, but now the great theme\r\nof the bonnet was thrown into perspective, and the children were out of\r\nthe way, yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s anxieties recurred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt weighs on my mind so as never was,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, by way of opening the\r\nsubject, \xe2\x80\x9csister Glegg\xe2\x80\x99s leaving the house in that way. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I\xe2\x80\x99d no\r\nwish t\xe2\x80\x99 offend a sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunt Pullet, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no accounting for what Jane \xe2\x80\x99ull do. I\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t speak of it out o\xe2\x80\x99 the family, if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to Dr Turnbull;\r\nbut it\xe2\x80\x99s my belief Jane lives too low. I\xe2\x80\x99ve said so to Pullet often and\r\noften, and he knows it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you said so last Monday was a week, when we came away from\r\ndrinking tea with \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Pullet, beginning to nurse his knee and\r\nshelter it with his pocket handkerchief, as was his way when the\r\nconversation took an interesting turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery like I did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, \xe2\x80\x9cfor you remember when I said\r\nthings, better than I can remember myself. He\xe2\x80\x99s got a wonderful memory,\r\nPullet has,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, looking pathetically at her sister. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshould be poorly off if he was to have a stroke, for he always\r\nremembers when I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to take my doctor\xe2\x80\x99s stuff; and I\xe2\x80\x99m taking three\r\nsorts now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s the \xe2\x80\x98pills as before\xe2\x80\x99 every other night, and the new drops at\r\neleven and four, and the \xe2\x80\x99fervescing mixture \xe2\x80\x98when agreeable,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nrehearsed Mr Pullet, with a punctuation determined by a lozenge on his\r\ntongue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, perhaps it \xe2\x80\x99ud be better for sister Glegg if _she\xe2\x80\x99d_ go to the\r\ndoctor sometimes, instead o\xe2\x80\x99 chewing Turkey rhubarb whenever there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanything the matter with her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, who naturally saw the\r\nwide subject of medicine chiefly in relation to Mrs Glegg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s dreadful to think on,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunt Pullet, raising her hands and\r\nletting them fall again, \xe2\x80\x9cpeople playing with their own insides in that\r\nway! And it\xe2\x80\x99s flying i\xe2\x80\x99 the face o\xe2\x80\x99 Providence; for what are the\r\ndoctors for, if we aren\xe2\x80\x99t to call \xe2\x80\x99em in? And when folks have got the\r\nmoney to pay for a doctor, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t respectable, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve told Jane many\r\na time. I\xe2\x80\x99m ashamed of acquaintance knowing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, _we\xe2\x80\x99ve_ no call to be ashamed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Pullet, \xe2\x80\x9cfor Doctor\r\nTurnbull hasn\xe2\x80\x99t got such another patient as you i\xe2\x80\x99 this parish, now old\r\nMrs Sutton\xe2\x80\x99s gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPullet keeps all my physic-bottles, did you know, Bessy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs\r\nPullet. \xe2\x80\x9cHe won\xe2\x80\x99t have one sold. He says it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing but right folks\r\nshould see \xe2\x80\x99em when I\xe2\x80\x99m gone. They fill two o\xe2\x80\x99 the long store-room\r\nshelves a\xe2\x80\x99ready; but,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, beginning to cry a little, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s well\r\nif they ever fill three. I may go before I\xe2\x80\x99ve made up the dozen o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthese last sizes. The pill-boxes are in the closet in my room,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nremember that, sister,\xe2\x80\x94but there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to show for the boluses, if\r\nit isn\xe2\x80\x99t the bills.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk o\xe2\x80\x99 your going, sister,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver; \xe2\x80\x9cI should have\r\nnobody to stand between me and sister Glegg if you was gone. And\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s nobody but you can get her to make it up with Mr Tulliver, for\r\nsister Deane\xe2\x80\x99s never o\xe2\x80\x99 my side, and if she was, it\xe2\x80\x99s not to be looked\r\nfor as she can speak like them as have got an independent fortin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, your husband _is_ awk\xe2\x80\x99ard, you know, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet,\r\ngood-naturedly ready to use her deep depression on her sister\xe2\x80\x99s account\r\nas well as her own. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s never behaved quite so pretty to our family\r\nas he should do, and the children take after him,\xe2\x80\x94the boy\xe2\x80\x99s very\r\nmischievous, and runs away from his aunts and uncles, and the gell\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrude and brown. It\xe2\x80\x99s your bad luck, and I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry for you, Bessy; for\r\nyou was allays my favourite sister, and we allays liked the same\r\npatterns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s hasty, and says odd things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver,\r\nwiping away one small tear from the corner of her eye; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99m sure\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s never been the man, since he married me, to object to my making\r\nthe friends o\xe2\x80\x99 my side o\xe2\x80\x99 the family welcome to the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t want to make the worst of you, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet,\r\ncompassionately, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I doubt you\xe2\x80\x99ll have trouble enough without that;\r\nand your husband\xe2\x80\x99s got that poor sister and her children hanging on\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x94and so given to lawing, they say. Not as I\xe2\x80\x99d have it said out o\xe2\x80\x99 the family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis view of her position was naturally far from cheering to Mrs\r\nTulliver. Her imagination was not easily acted on, but she could not\r\nhelp thinking that her case was a hard one, since it appeared that\r\nother people thought it hard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure, sister, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help myself,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, urged by the fear\r\nlest her anticipated misfortunes might be held retributive, to take\r\ncomprehensive review of her past conduct. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no woman strives\r\nmore for her children; and I\xe2\x80\x99m sure at scouring-time this Lady-day as\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve had all the bedhangings taken down I did as much as the two gells\r\nput together; and there\xe2\x80\x99s the last elder-flower wine I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nmade\xe2\x80\x94beautiful! I allays offer it along with the sherry, though sister\r\nGlegg will have it I\xe2\x80\x99m so extravagant; and as for liking to have my\r\nclothes tidy, and not go a fright about the house, there\xe2\x80\x99s nobody in\r\nthe parish can say anything against me in respect o\xe2\x80\x99 backbiting and\r\nmaking mischief, for I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish anybody any harm; and nobody loses by\r\nsending me a porkpie, for my pies are fit to show with the best o\xe2\x80\x99 my\r\nneighbours\xe2\x80\x99; and the linen\xe2\x80\x99s so in order as if I was to die to-morrow I\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be ashamed. A woman can do no more nor she can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it\xe2\x80\x99s all o\xe2\x80\x99 no use, you know, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, holding her\r\nhead on one side, and fixing her eyes pathetically on her sister, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nyour husband makes away with his money. Not but what if you was sold\r\nup, and other folks bought your furniture, it\xe2\x80\x99s a comfort to think as\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve kept it well rubbed. And there\xe2\x80\x99s the linen, with your maiden\r\nmark on, might go all over the country. It \xe2\x80\x99ud be a sad pity for our\r\nfamily.\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs Pullet shook her head slowly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what can I do, sister?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver. \xe2\x80\x9cMr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s not a\r\nman to be dictated to,\xe2\x80\x94not if I was to go to the parson and get by\r\nheart what I should tell my husband for the best. And I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\npretend to know anything about putting out money and all that. I could\r\nnever see into men\xe2\x80\x99s business as sister Glegg does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99re like me in that, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet; \xe2\x80\x9cand I think it\r\n\xe2\x80\x99ud be a deal more becoming o\xe2\x80\x99 Jane if she\xe2\x80\x99d have that pier-glass\r\nrubbed oftener,\xe2\x80\x94there was ever so many spots on it last week,\xe2\x80\x94instead\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 dictating to folks as have more comings in than she ever had, and\r\ntelling \xe2\x80\x99em what they\xe2\x80\x99re to do with their money. But Jane and me were\r\nallays contrairy; she _would_ have striped things, and I like spots.\r\nYou like a spot too, Bessy; we allays hung together i\xe2\x80\x99 that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sophy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, \xe2\x80\x9cI remember our having a blue ground\r\nwith a white spot both alike,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a bit in a bed-quilt now; and if\r\nyou would but go and see sister Glegg, and persuade her to make it up\r\nwith Tulliver, I should take it very kind of you. You was allays a good\r\nsister to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the right thing \xe2\x80\x99ud be for Tulliver to go and make it up with her\r\nhimself, and say he was sorry for speaking so rash. If he\xe2\x80\x99s borrowed\r\nmoney of her, he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be above that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, whose\r\npartiality did not blind her to principles; she did not forget what was\r\ndue to people of independent fortune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no use talking o\xe2\x80\x99 that,\xe2\x80\x9d said poor Mrs Tulliver, almost\r\npeevishly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I was to go down on my bare knees on the gravel to\r\nTulliver, he\xe2\x80\x99d never humble himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can\xe2\x80\x99t expect me to persuade _Jane_ to beg pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs\r\nPullet. \xe2\x80\x9cHer temper\xe2\x80\x99s beyond everything; it\xe2\x80\x99s well if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t carry\r\nher off her mind, though there never _was_ any of our family went to a\r\nmadhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not thinking of her begging pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99d just take no notice, and not call her money in; as it\xe2\x80\x99s not so\r\nmuch for one sister to ask of another; time \xe2\x80\x99ud mend things, and\r\nTulliver \xe2\x80\x99ud forget all about it, and they\xe2\x80\x99d be friends again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Tulliver, you perceive, was not aware of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s irrevocable\r\ndetermination to pay in the five hundred pounds; at least such a\r\ndetermination exceeded her powers of belief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, mournfully, \xe2\x80\x9c_I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t want to help you\r\non to ruin. I won\xe2\x80\x99t be behindhand i\xe2\x80\x99 doing you a good turn, if it is to\r\nbe done. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it said among acquaintance as we\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\nquarrels in the family. I shall tell Jane that; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind\r\ndriving to Jane\xe2\x80\x99s tomorrow, if Pullet doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mind. What do you say, Mr\r\nPullet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve no objections,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Pullet, who was perfectly contented with\r\nany course the quarrel might take, so that Mr Tulliver did not apply to\r\n_him_ for money. Mr Pullet was nervous about his investments, and did\r\nnot see how a man could have any security for his money unless he\r\nturned it into land.\r\n\r\nAfter a little further discussion as to whether it would not be better\r\nfor Mrs Tulliver to accompany them on a visit to sister Glegg, Mrs\r\nPullet, observing that it was tea-time, turned to reach from a drawer a\r\ndelicate damask napkin, which she pinned before her in the fashion of\r\nan apron. The door did, in fact, soon open, but instead of the\r\ntea-tray, Sally introduced an object so startling that both Mrs Pullet\r\nand Mrs Tulliver gave a scream, causing uncle Pullet to swallow his\r\nlozenge\xe2\x80\x94for the fifth time in his life, as he afterward noted.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter X.\r\n\r\nMaggie Behaves Worse Than She Expected\r\n\r\nThe startling object which thus made an epoch for uncle Pullet was no\r\nother than little Lucy, with one side of her person, from her small\r\nfoot to her bonnet-crown, wet and discoloured with mud, holding out two\r\ntiny blackened hands, and making a very piteous face. To account for\r\nthis unprecedented apparition in aunt Pullet\xe2\x80\x99s parlour, we must return\r\nto the moment when the three children went to play out of doors, and\r\nthe small demons who had taken possession of Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s soul at an early\r\nperiod of the day had returned in all the greater force after a\r\ntemporary absence. All the disagreeable recollections of the morning\r\nwere thick upon her, when Tom, whose displeasure toward her had been\r\nconsiderably refreshed by her foolish trick of causing him to upset his\r\ncowslip wine, said, \xe2\x80\x9cHere, Lucy, you come along with me,\xe2\x80\x9d and walked\r\noff to the area where the toads were, as if there were no Maggie in\r\nexistence. Seeing this, Maggie lingered at a distance, looking like a\r\nsmall Medusa with her snakes cropped. Lucy was naturally pleased that\r\ncousin Tom was so good to her, and it was very amusing to see him\r\ntickling a fat toad with a piece of string when the toad was safe down\r\nthe area, with an iron grating over him. Still Lucy wished Maggie to\r\nenjoy the spectacle also, especially as she would doubtless find a name\r\nfor the toad, and say what had been his past history; for Lucy had a\r\ndelighted semi-belief in Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s stories about the live things they\r\ncame upon by accident,\xe2\x80\x94how Mrs Earwig had a wash at home, and one of\r\nher children had fallen into the hot copper, for which reason she was\r\nrunning so fast to fetch the doctor. Tom had a profound contempt for\r\nthis nonsense of Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s, smashing the earwig at once as a superfluous\r\nyet easy means of proving the entire unreality of such a story; but\r\nLucy, for the life of her, could not help fancying there was something\r\nin it, and at all events thought it was very pretty make-believe.
