Who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t laugh at the\r\nidea of _your_ turning lover to a fine girl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom and Maggie walked on in silence for some yards. He burst out, in a\r\nconvulsed voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Maggie!\xe2\x80\x9d said Philip, making a strong effort to speak. Then\r\nlooking at Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have dragged your sister here, I suppose, that she\r\nmay stand by while you threaten and insult me. These naturally seemed\r\nto you the right means to influence me. But you are mistaken. Let your\r\nsister speak. If she says she is bound to give me up, I shall abide by\r\nher wishes to the slightest word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was for my father\xe2\x80\x99s sake, Philip,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, imploringly. \xe2\x80\x9cTom\r\nthreatens to tell my father, and he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear it; I have promised,\r\nI have vowed solemnly, that we will not have any intercourse without my\r\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is enough, Maggie. _I_ shall not change; but I wish you to hold\r\nyourself entirely free. But trust me; remember that I can never seek\r\nfor anything but good to what belongs to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, exasperated by this attitude of Philip\xe2\x80\x99s, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can\r\ntalk of seeking good for her and what belongs to her now; did you seek\r\nher good before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did,\xe2\x80\x94at some risk, perhaps. But I wished her to have a friend for\r\nlife,\xe2\x80\x94who would cherish her, who would do her more justice than a\r\ncoarse and narrow-minded brother, that she has always lavished her\r\naffections on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my way of befriending her is different from yours; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell\r\nyou what is my way. I\xe2\x80\x99ll save her from disobeying and disgracing her\r\nfather; I\xe2\x80\x99ll save her from throwing herself away on you,\xe2\x80\x94from making\r\nherself a laughing-stock,\xe2\x80\x94from being flouted by a man like _your_\r\nfather, because she\xe2\x80\x99s not good enough for his son. You know well enough\r\nwhat sort of justice and cherishing you were preparing for her. I\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\nto be imposed upon by fine words; I can see what actions mean. Come\r\naway, Maggie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe seized Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s right wrist as he spoke, and she put out her left\r\nhand. Philip clasped it an instant, with one eager look, and then\r\nhurried away.\r\n\r\nTom and Maggie walked on in silence for some yards. He was still\r\nholding her wrist tightly, as if he were compelling a culprit from the\r\nscene of action. At last Maggie, with a violent snatch, drew her hand\r\naway, and her pent-up, long-gathered irritation burst into utterance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t suppose that I think you are right, Tom, or that I bow to your\r\nwill. I despise the feelings you have shown in speaking to Philip; I\r\ndetest your insulting, unmanly allusions to his deformity. You have\r\nbeen reproaching other people all your life; you have been always sure\r\nyou yourself are right. It is because you have not a mind large enough\r\nto see that there is anything better than your own conduct and your own\r\npetty aims.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, coolly. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see that your conduct is\r\nbetter, or your aims either. If your conduct, and Philip Wakem\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconduct, has been right, why are you ashamed of its being known? Answer\r\nme that. I know what I have aimed at in my conduct, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve succeeded;\r\npray, what good has your conduct brought to you or any one else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to defend myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, still with vehemence: \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknow I\xe2\x80\x99ve been wrong,\xe2\x80\x94often, continually. But yet, sometimes when I\r\nhave done wrong, it has been because I have feelings that you would be\r\nthe better for, if you had them. If _you_ were in fault ever, if you\r\nhad done anything very wrong, I should be sorry for the pain it brought\r\nyou; I should not want punishment to be heaped on you. But you have\r\nalways enjoyed punishing me; you have always been hard and cruel to me;\r\neven when I was a little girl, and always loved you better than any one\r\nelse in the world, you would let me go crying to bed without forgiving\r\nme. You have no pity; you have no sense of your own imperfection and\r\nyour own sins. It is a sin to be hard; it is not fitting for a mortal,\r\nfor a Christian. You are nothing but a Pharisee. You thank God for\r\nnothing but your own virtues; you think they are great enough to win\r\nyou everything else. You have not even a vision of feelings by the side\r\nof which your shining virtues are mere darkness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with cold scorn, \xe2\x80\x9cif your feelings are so much better\r\nthan mine, let me see you show them in some other way than by conduct\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s likely to disgrace us all,\xe2\x80\x94than by ridiculous flights first into\r\none extreme and then into another. Pray, how have you shown your love,\r\nthat you talk of, either to me or my father? By disobeying and\r\ndeceiving us. I have a different way of showing my affection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you are a man, Tom, and have power, and can do something in\r\nthe world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, if you can do nothing, submit to those that can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I _will_ submit to what I acknowledge and feel to be right. I will\r\nsubmit even to what is unreasonable from my father, but I will not\r\nsubmit to it from you. You boast of your virtues as if they purchased\r\nyou a right to be cruel and unmanly, as you\xe2\x80\x99ve been to-day. Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsuppose I would give up Philip Wakem in obedience to you. The deformity\r\nyou insult would make me cling to him and care for him the more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; that is your view of things.\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, more coldly than\r\never; \xe2\x80\x9cyou need say no more to show me what a wide distance there is\r\nbetween us. Let us remember that in future, and be silent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom went back to St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s, to fulfill an appointment with his uncle\r\nDeane, and receive directions about a journey on which he was to set\r\nout the next morning.\r\n\r\nMaggie went up to her own room to pour out all that indignant\r\nremonstrance, against which Tom\xe2\x80\x99s mind was close barred, in bitter\r\ntears. Then, when the first burst of unsatisfied anger was gone by,\r\ncame the recollection of that quiet time before the pleasure which had\r\nended in to-day\xe2\x80\x99s misery had perturbed the clearness and simplicity of\r\nher life. She used to think in that time that she had made great\r\nconquests, and won a lasting stand on serene heights above worldly\r\ntemptations and conflict. And here she was down again in the thick of a\r\nhot strife with her own and others\xe2\x80\x99 passions. Life was not so short,\r\nthen, and perfect rest was not so near as she had dreamed when she was\r\ntwo years younger. There was more struggle for her, and perhaps more\r\nfalling. If she had felt that she was entirely wrong, and that Tom had\r\nbeen entirely right, she could sooner have recovered more inward\r\nharmony; but now her penitence and submission were constantly\r\nobstructed by resentment that would present itself to her no otherwise\r\nthan as a just indignation. Her heart bled for Philip; she went on\r\nrecalling the insults that had been flung at him with so vivid a\r\nconception of what he had felt under them, that it was almost like a\r\nsharp bodily pain to her, making her beat the floor with her foot and\r\ntighten her fingers on her palm.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, how was it that she was now and then conscious of a certain\r\ndim background of relief in the forced separation from Philip? Surely\r\nit was only because the sense of a deliverance from concealment was\r\nwelcome at any cost.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VI.\r\n\r\nThe Hard-Won Triumph\r\n\r\nThree weeks later, when Dorlcote Mill was at its prettiest moment in\r\nall the year,\xe2\x80\x94the great chestnuts in blossom, and the grass all deep\r\nand daisied,\xe2\x80\x94Tom Tulliver came home to it earlier than usual in the\r\nevening, and as he passed over the bridge, he looked with the old\r\ndeep-rooted affection at the respectable red brick house, which always\r\nseemed cheerful and inviting outside, let the rooms be as bare and the\r\nhearts as sad as they might inside. There is a very pleasant light in\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s blue-gray eyes as he glances at the house-windows; that fold in\r\nhis brow never disappears, but it is not unbecoming; it seems to imply\r\na strength of will that may possibly be without harshness, when the\r\neyes and mouth have their gentlest expression. His firm step becomes\r\nquicker, and the corners of his mouth rebel against the compression\r\nwhich is meant to forbid a smile.\r\n\r\nThe eyes in the parlour were not turned toward the bridge just then,\r\nand the group there was sitting in unexpectant silence,\xe2\x80\x94Mr Tulliver in\r\nhis arm-chair, tired with a long ride, and ruminating with a worn look,\r\nfixed chiefly on Maggie, who was bending over her sewing while her\r\nmother was making the tea.\r\n\r\nThey all looked up with surprise when they heard the well-known foot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what\xe2\x80\x99s up now, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d said his father. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a bit earlier than\r\nusual.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there was nothing more for me to do, so I came away. Well,\r\nmother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom went up to his mother and kissed her, a sign of unusual good-humour\r\nwith him. Hardly a word or look had passed between him and Maggie in\r\nall the three weeks; but his usual incommunicativeness at home\r\nprevented this from being noticeable to their parents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, when they had finished tea, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know exactly\r\nhow much money there is in the tin box?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly a hundred and ninety-three pound,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbrought less o\xe2\x80\x99 late; but young fellows like to have their own way with\r\ntheir money. Though I didn\xe2\x80\x99t do as I liked before _I_ was of age.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nspoke with rather timid discontent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite sure that\xe2\x80\x99s the sum, father?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you\r\nwould take the trouble to fetch the tin box down. I think you have\r\nperhaps made a mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow should I make a mistake?\xe2\x80\x9d said his father, sharply. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve counted\r\nit often enough; but I can fetch it, if you won\xe2\x80\x99t believe me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was always an incident Mr Tulliver liked, in his gloomy life, to\r\nfetch the tin box and count the money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t go out of the room, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, as he saw her moving when\r\nhis father was gone upstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd isn\xe2\x80\x99t Maggie to go?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver; \xe2\x80\x9cbecause somebody must\r\ntake away the things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as she likes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom indifferently.\r\n\r\nThat was a cutting word to Maggie. Her heart had leaped with the sudden\r\nconviction that Tom was going to tell their father the debts could be\r\npaid; and Tom would have let her be absent when that news was told! But\r\nshe carried away the tray and came back immediately. The feeling of\r\ninjury on her own behalf could not predominate at that moment.\r\n\r\nTom drew to the corner of the table near his father when the tin box\r\nwas set down and opened, and the red evening light falling on them made\r\nconspicuous the worn, sour gloom of the dark-eyed father and the\r\nsuppressed joy in the face of the fair-complexioned son. The mother and\r\nMaggie sat at the other end of the table, the one in blank patience,\r\nthe other in palpitating expectation.\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver counted out the money, setting it in order on the table,\r\nand then said, glancing sharply at Tom:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now! you see I was right enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused, looking at the money with bitter despondency.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s more nor three hundred wanting; it\xe2\x80\x99ll be a fine while before\r\n_I_ can save that. Losing that forty-two pound wi\xe2\x80\x99 the corn was a sore\r\njob. This world\xe2\x80\x99s been too many for me. It\xe2\x80\x99s took four year to lay\r\n_this_ by; it\xe2\x80\x99s much if I\xe2\x80\x99m above ground for another four year. I must\r\ntrusten to you to pay \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, with a trembling voice, \xe2\x80\x9cif you\r\nkeep i\xe2\x80\x99 the same mind now you\xe2\x80\x99re coming o\xe2\x80\x99 age. But you\xe2\x80\x99re like enough\r\nto bury me first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked up in Tom\xe2\x80\x99s face with a querulous desire for some assurance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, speaking with energetic decision, though there\r\nwas tremor discernible in his voice too, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will live to see the\r\ndebts all paid. You shall pay them with your own hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis tone implied something more than mere hopefulness or resolution. A\r\nslight electric shock seemed to pass through Mr Tulliver, and he kept\r\nhis eyes fixed on Tom with a look of eager inquiry, while Maggie,\r\nunable to restrain herself, rushed to her father\xe2\x80\x99s side and knelt down\r\nby him. Tom was silent a little while before he went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good while ago, my uncle Glegg lent me a little money to trade with,\r\nand that has answered. I have three hundred and twenty pounds in the\r\nbank.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis mother\xe2\x80\x99s arms were round his neck as soon as the last words were\r\nuttered, and she said, half crying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my boy, I knew you\xe2\x80\x99d make iverything right again, when you got a\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut his father was silent; the flood of emotion hemmed in all power of\r\nspeech. Both Tom and Maggie were struck with fear lest the shock of joy\r\nmight even be fatal. But the blessed relief of tears came. The broad\r\nchest heaved, the muscles of the face gave way, and the gray-haired man\r\nburst into loud sobs. The fit of weeping gradually subsided, and he sat\r\nquiet, recovering the regularity of his breathing. At last he looked up\r\nat his wife and said, in a gentle tone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBessy, you must come and kiss me now\xe2\x80\x94the lad has made you amends.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99ll see a bit o\xe2\x80\x99 comfort again, belike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen she had kissed him, and he had held her hand a minute, his\r\nthoughts went back to the money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you\xe2\x80\x99d brought me the money to look at, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, fingering\r\nthe sovereigns on the table; \xe2\x80\x9cI should ha\xe2\x80\x99 felt surer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall see it to-morrow, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cMy uncle Deane has\r\nappointed the creditors to meet to-morrow at the Golden Lion, and he\r\nhas ordered a dinner for them at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock. My uncle Glegg and he\r\nwill both be there. It was advertised in the \xe2\x80\x98Messenger\xe2\x80\x99 on Saturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Wakem knows on\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, his eye kindling with\r\ntriumphant fire. \xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, with a long-drawn guttural\r\nenunciation, taking out his snuff-box, the only luxury he had left\r\nhimself, and tapping it with something of his old air of defiance.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get from under _his_ thumb now, though I _must_ leave the old\r\nmill. I thought I could ha\xe2\x80\x99 held out to die here\xe2\x80\x94but I can\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\na glass o\xe2\x80\x99 nothing in the house, have we, Bessy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver, drawing out her much-reduced bunch of keys,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s some brandy sister Deane brought me when I was ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet it me, then; get it me. I feel a bit weak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, my lad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a stronger voice, when he had taken some\r\nbrandy-and-water, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall make a speech to \xe2\x80\x99em. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell \xe2\x80\x99em it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nyou as got the best part o\xe2\x80\x99 the money. They\xe2\x80\x99ll see I\xe2\x80\x99m honest at last,\r\nand ha\xe2\x80\x99 got an honest son. Ah! Wakem \xe2\x80\x99ud be fine and glad to have a son\r\nlike mine,\xe2\x80\x94a fine straight fellow,\xe2\x80\x94i\xe2\x80\x99stead o\xe2\x80\x99 that poor crooked\r\ncreatur! You\xe2\x80\x99ll prosper i\xe2\x80\x99 the world, my lad; you\xe2\x80\x99ll maybe see the day\r\nwhen Wakem and his son \xe2\x80\x99ull be a round or two below you. You\xe2\x80\x99ll like\r\nenough be ta\xe2\x80\x99en into partnership, as your uncle Deane was before\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re in the right way for\xe2\x80\x99t; and then there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to hinder\r\nyour getting rich. And if ever you\xe2\x80\x99re rich enough\xe2\x80\x94mind this\xe2\x80\x94try and get\r\nth\xe2\x80\x99 old mill again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver threw himself back in his chair; his mind, which had so\r\nlong been the home of nothing but bitter discontent and foreboding,\r\nsuddenly filled, by the magic of joy, with visions of good fortune. But\r\nsome subtle influence prevented him from foreseeing the good fortune as\r\nhappening to himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShake hands wi\xe2\x80\x99 me, my lad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, suddenly putting out his hand.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a great thing when a man can be proud as he\xe2\x80\x99s got a good son.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve had _that_ luck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom never lived to taste another moment so delicious as that; and\r\nMaggie couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help forgetting her own grievances. Tom _was_ good; and\r\nin the sweet humility that springs in us all in moments of true\r\nadmiration and gratitude, she felt that the faults he had to pardon in\r\nher had never been redeemed, as his faults were. She felt no jealousy\r\nthis evening that, for the first time, she seemed to be thrown into the\r\nbackground in her father\xe2\x80\x99s mind.\r\n\r\nThere was much more talk before bedtime. Mr Tulliver naturally wanted\r\nto hear all the particulars of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s trading adventures, and he\r\nlistened with growing excitement and delight. He was curious to know\r\nwhat had been said on every occasion; if possible, what had been\r\nthought; and Bob Jakin\xe2\x80\x99s part in the business threw him into peculiar\r\noutbursts of sympathy with the triumphant knowingness of that\r\nremarkable packman. Bob\xe2\x80\x99s juvenile history, so far as it had come under\r\nMr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge, was recalled with that sense of astonishing\r\npromise it displayed, which is observable in all reminiscences of the\r\nchildhood of great men.\r\n\r\nIt was well that there was this interest of narrative to keep under the\r\nvague but fierce sense of triumph over Wakem, which would otherwise\r\nhave been the channel his joy would have rushed into with dangerous\r\nforce. Even as it was, that feeling from time to time gave threats of\r\nits ultimate mastery, in sudden bursts of irrelevant exclamation.\r\n\r\nIt was long before Mr Tulliver got to sleep that night; and the sleep,\r\nwhen it came, was filled with vivid dreams. At half-past five o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nin the morning, when Mrs Tulliver was already rising, he alarmed her by\r\nstarting up with a sort of smothered shout, and looking round in a\r\nbewildered way at the walls of the bedroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, Mr Tulliver?\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife. He looked at her,\r\nstill with a puzzled expression, and said at last:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x94I was dreaming\xe2\x80\x94did I make a noise?\xe2\x80\x94I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d got hold of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII.\r\n\r\nA Day of Reckoning\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver was an essentially sober man,\xe2\x80\x94able to take his glass and\r\nnot averse to it, but never exceeding the bounds of moderation. He had\r\nnaturally an active Hotspur temperament, which did not crave liquid\r\nfire to set it aglow; his impetuosity was usually equal to an exciting\r\noccasion without any such reinforcements; and his desire for the\r\nbrandy-and-water implied that the too sudden joy had fallen with a\r\ndangerous shock on a frame depressed by four years of gloom and\r\nunaccustomed hard fare. But that first doubtful tottering moment\r\npassed, he seemed to gather strength with his gathering excitement; and\r\nthe next day, when he was seated at table with his creditors, his eye\r\nkindling and his cheek flushed with the consciousness that he was about\r\nto make an honourable figure once more, he looked more like the proud,\r\nconfident, warm-hearted, and warm-tempered Tulliver of old times than\r\nmight have seemed possible to any one who had met him a week before,\r\nriding along as had been his wont for the last four years since the\r\nsense of failure and debt had been upon him,\xe2\x80\x94with his head hanging\r\ndown, casting brief, unwilling looks on those who forced themselves on\r\nhis notice. He made his speech, asserting his honest principles with\r\nhis old confident eagerness, alluding to the rascals and the luck that\r\nhad been against him, but that he had triumphed over, to some extent,\r\nby hard efforts and the aid of a good son; and winding up with the\r\nstory of how Tom had got the best part of the needful money. But the\r\nstreak of irritation and hostile triumph seemed to melt for a little\r\nwhile into purer fatherly pride and pleasure, when, Tom\xe2\x80\x99s health having\r\nbeen proposed, and uncle Deane having taken occasion to say a few words\r\nof eulogy on his general character and conduct, Tom himself got up and\r\nmade the single speech of his life. It could hardly have been briefer.\r\nHe thanked the gentlemen for the honour they had done him. He was glad\r\nthat he had been able to help his father in proving his integrity and\r\nregaining his honest name; and, for his own part, he hoped he should\r\nnever undo that work and disgrace that name. But the applause that\r\nfollowed was so great, and Tom looked so gentlemanly as well as tall\r\nand straight, that Mr Tulliver remarked, in an explanatory manner, to\r\nhis friends on his right and left, that he had spent a deal of money on\r\nhis son\xe2\x80\x99s education.\r\n\r\nThe party broke up in very sober fashion at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock. Tom remained\r\nin St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s to attend to some business, and Mr Tulliver mounted his\r\nhorse to go home, and describe the memorable things that had been said\r\nand done, to \xe2\x80\x9cpoor Bessy and the little wench.\xe2\x80\x9d The air of excitement\r\nthat hung about him was but faintly due to good cheer or any stimulus\r\nbut the potent wine of triumphant joy. He did not choose any back\r\nstreet to-day, but rode slowly, with uplifted head and free glances,\r\nalong the principal street all the way to the bridge.\r\n\r\nWhy did he not happen to meet Wakem? The want of that coincidence vexed\r\nhim, and set his mind at work in an irritating way. Perhaps Wakem was\r\ngone out of town to-day on purpose to avoid seeing or hearing anything\r\nof an honourable action which might well cause him some unpleasant\r\ntwinges. If Wakem were to meet him then, Mr Tulliver would look\r\nstraight at him, and the rascal would perhaps be forsaken a little by\r\nhis cool, domineering impudence. He would know by and by that an honest\r\nman was not going to serve _him_ any longer, and lend his honesty to\r\nfill a pocket already over-full of dishonest gains. Perhaps the luck\r\nwas beginning to turn; perhaps the Devil didn\xe2\x80\x99t always hold the best\r\ncards in this world.\r\n\r\nSimmering in this way, Mr Tulliver approached the yardgates of Dorlcote\r\nMill, near enough to see a well-known figure coming out of them on a\r\nfine black horse. They met about fifty yards from the gates, between\r\nthe great chestnuts and elms and the high bank.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTulliver,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wakem, abruptly, in a haughtier tone than usual, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\na fool\xe2\x80\x99s trick you did,\xe2\x80\x94spreading those hard lumps on that Far Close! I\r\ntold you how it would be; but you men never learn to farm with any\r\nmethod.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tulliver, suddenly boiling up; \xe2\x80\x9cget somebody else to farm\r\nfor you, then, as\xe2\x80\x99ll ask _you_ to teach him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have been drinking, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wakem, really believing that\r\nthis was the meaning of Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s flushed face and sparkling eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I\xe2\x80\x99ve not been drinking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tulliver; \xe2\x80\x9cI want no drinking to\r\nhelp me make up my mind as I\xe2\x80\x99ll serve no longer under a scoundrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well! you may leave my premises to-morrow, then; hold your\r\ninsolent tongue and let me pass.\xe2\x80\x9d (Tulliver was backing his horse\r\nacross the road to hem Wakem in.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I _sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t_ let you pass,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tulliver, getting fiercer. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshall tell you what I think of you first. You\xe2\x80\x99re too big a raskill to\r\nget hanged\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me pass, you ignorant brute, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll ride over you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Tulliver, spurring his horse and raising his whip, made a rush\r\nforward; and Wakem\xe2\x80\x99s horse, rearing and staggering backward, threw his\r\nrider from the saddle and sent him sideways on the ground. Wakem had\r\nhad the presence of mind to loose the bridle at once, and as the horse\r\nonly staggered a few paces and then stood still, he might have risen\r\nand remounted without more inconvenience than a bruise and a shake. But\r\nbefore he could rise, Tulliver was off his horse too. The sight of the\r\nlong-hated predominant man down, and in his power, threw him into a\r\nfrenzy of triumphant vengeance, which seemed to give him preternatural\r\nagility and strength. He rushed on Wakem, who was in the act of trying\r\nto recover his feet, grasped him by the left arm so as to press Wakem\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhole weight on the right arm, which rested on the ground, and flogged\r\nhim fiercely across the back with his riding-whip. Wakem shouted for\r\nhelp, but no help came, until a woman\xe2\x80\x99s scream was heard, and the cry\r\nof \xe2\x80\x9cFather, father!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly, Wakem felt, something had arrested Mr Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s arm; for the\r\nflogging ceased, and the grasp on his own arm was relaxed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet away with you\xe2\x80\x94go!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tulliver, angrily. But it was not to Wakem\r\nthat he spoke. Slowly the lawyer rose, and, as he turned his head, saw\r\nthat Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s arms were being held by a girl, rather by the fear of\r\nhurting the girl that clung to him with all her young might.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Luke\xe2\x80\x94mother\xe2\x80\x94come and help Mr Wakem!\xe2\x80\x9d Maggie cried, as she heard\r\nthe longed-for footsteps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp me on to that low horse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wakem to Luke, \xe2\x80\x9cthen I shall\r\nperhaps manage; though\xe2\x80\x94confound it\xe2\x80\x94I think this arm is sprained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith some difficulty, Wakem was heaved on to Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s horse. Then he\r\nturned toward the miller and said, with white rage, \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll suffer for\r\nthis, sir. Your daughter is a witness that you\xe2\x80\x99ve assaulted me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Tulliver, in a thick, fierce voice; \xe2\x80\x9cgo and\r\nshow your back, and tell \xe2\x80\x99em I thrashed you. Tell \xe2\x80\x99em I\xe2\x80\x99ve made things\r\na bit more even i\xe2\x80\x99 the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRide my horse home with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wakem to Luke. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the Tofton Ferry,\r\nnot through the town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, come in!\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, imploringly. Then, seeing that Wakem\r\nhad ridden off, and that no further violence was possible, she\r\nslackened her hold and burst into hysteric sobs, while poor Mrs\r\nTulliver stood by in silence, quivering with fear. But Maggie became\r\nconscious that as she was slackening her hold her father was beginning\r\nto grasp her and lean on her. The surprise checked her sobs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel ill\xe2\x80\x94faintish,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cHelp me in, Bessy\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m giddy\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve a\r\npain i\xe2\x80\x99 the head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe walked in slowly, propped by his wife and daughter and tottered into\r\nhis arm-chair. The almost purple flush had given way to paleness, and\r\nhis hand was cold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHadn\xe2\x80\x99t we better send for the doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Tulliver.\r\n\r\nHe seemed to be too faint and suffering to hear her; but presently,\r\nwhen she said to Maggie, \xe2\x80\x9cGo and seek for somebody to fetch the\r\ndoctor,\xe2\x80\x9d he looked up at her with full comprehension, and said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoctor? No\xe2\x80\x94no doctor. It\xe2\x80\x99s my head, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Help me to bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSad ending to the day that had risen on them all like a beginning of\r\nbetter times! But mingled seed must bear a mingled crop.\r\n\r\nIn half an hour after his father had lain down Tom came home. Bob Jakin\r\nwas with him, come to congratulate \xe2\x80\x9cthe old master,\xe2\x80\x9d not without some\r\nexcusable pride that he had had his share in bringing about Mr Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngood luck; and Tom had thought his father would like nothing better, as\r\na finish to the day, than a talk with Bob. But now Tom could only spend\r\nthe evening in gloomy expectation of the unpleasant consequences that\r\nmust follow on this mad outbreak of his father\xe2\x80\x99s long-smothered hate.\r\nAfter the painful news had been told, he sat in silence; he had not\r\nspirit or inclination to tell his mother and sister anything about the\r\ndinner; they hardly cared to ask it. Apparently the mingled thread in\r\nthe web of their life was so curiously twisted together that there\r\ncould be no joy without a sorrow coming close upon it. Tom was dejected\r\nby the thought that his exemplary effort must always be baffled by the\r\nwrong-doing of others; Maggie was living through, over and over again,\r\nthe agony of the moment in which she had rushed to throw herself on her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s arm, with a vague, shuddering foreboding of wretched scenes to\r\ncome. Not one of the three felt any particular alarm about Mr\r\nTulliver\xe2\x80\x99s health; the symptoms did not recall his former dangerous\r\nattack, and it seemed only a necessary consequence that his violent\r\npassion and effort of strength, after many hours of unusual excitement,\r\nshould have made him feel ill. Rest would probably cure him.\r\n\r\nTom, tired out by his active day, fell asleep soon, and slept soundly;\r\nit seemed to him as if he had only just come to bed, when he waked to\r\nsee his mother standing by him in the gray light of early morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy, you must get up this minute; I\xe2\x80\x99ve sent for the doctor, and\r\nyour father wants you and Maggie to come to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he worse, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s been very ill all night with his head, but he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nworse; he only said suddenly, \xe2\x80\x98Bessy, fetch the boy and girl. Tell \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nto make haste.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaggie and Tom threw on their clothes hastily in the chill gray light,\r\nand reached their father\xe2\x80\x99s room almost at the same moment. He was\r\nwatching for them with an expression of pain on his brow, but with\r\nsharpened, anxious consciousness in his eyes. Mrs Tulliver stood at the\r\nfoot of the bed, frightened and trembling, looking worn and aged from\r\ndisturbed rest. Maggie was at the bedside first, but her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nglance was toward Tom, who came and stood next to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, my lad, it\xe2\x80\x99s come upon me as I sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t get up again. This world\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeen too many for me, my lad, but you\xe2\x80\x99ve done what you could to make\r\nthings a bit even. Shake hands wi\xe2\x80\x99 me again, my lad, before I go away\r\nfrom you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe father and son clasped hands and looked at each other an instant.\r\nThen Tom said, trying to speak firmly,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any wish, father\xe2\x80\x94that I can fulfil, when\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, my lad\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll try and get the old mill back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there\xe2\x80\x99s your mother\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll try and make her amends, all you can,\r\nfor my bad luck\xe2\x80\x94and there\xe2\x80\x99s the little wench\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe father turned his eyes on Maggie with a still more eager look,\r\nwhile she, with a bursting heart, sank on her knees, to be closer to\r\nthe dear, time-worn face which had been present with her through long\r\nyears, as the sign of her deepest love and hardest trial.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must take care of her, Tom\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you fret, my wench\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99ll come\r\nsomebody as\xe2\x80\x99ll love you and take your part\xe2\x80\x94and you must be good to her,\r\nmy lad. I was good to _my_ sister. Kiss me, Maggie.\xe2\x80\x94Come, Bessy.\xe2\x80\x94You\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nmanage to pay for a brick grave, Tom, so as your mother and me can lie\r\ntogether.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked away from them all when he had said this, and lay silent for\r\nsome minutes, while they stood watching him, not daring to move. The\r\nmorning light was growing clearer for them, and they could see the\r\nheaviness gathering in his face, and the dulness in his eyes. But at\r\nlast he looked toward Tom and said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had my turn\xe2\x80\x94I beat him. That was nothing but fair. I never wanted\r\nanything but what was fair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, father, dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, an unspeakable anxiety\r\npredominating over her grief, \xe2\x80\x9cyou forgive him\xe2\x80\x94you forgive every one\r\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe did not move his eyes to look at her, but he said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my wench. I don\xe2\x80\x99t forgive him. What\xe2\x80\x99s forgiving to do? I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlove a raskill\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis voice had become thicker; but he wanted to say more, and moved his\r\nlips again and again, struggling in vain to speak. At length the words\r\nforced their way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes God forgive raskills?\xe2\x80\x94but if He does, He won\xe2\x80\x99t be hard wi\xe2\x80\x99 me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis hands moved uneasily, as if he wanted them to remove some\r\nobstruction that weighed upon him. Two or three times there fell from\r\nhim some broken words,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis world\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94too many\xe2\x80\x94honest man\xe2\x80\x94puzzling\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSoon they merged into mere mutterings; the eyes had ceased to discern;\r\nand then came the final silence.\r\n\r\nBut not of death. For an hour or more the chest heaved, the loud, hard\r\nbreathing continued, getting gradually slower, as the cold dews\r\ngathered on the brow.\r\n\r\nAt last there was total stillness, and poor Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s dimly lighted\r\nsoul had forever ceased to be vexed with the painful riddle of this\r\nworld.\r\n\r\nHelp was come now; Luke and his wife were there, and Mr Turnbull had\r\narrived, too late for everything but to say, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom and Maggie went downstairs together into the room where their\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s place was empty. Their eyes turned to the same spot, and\r\nMaggie spoke,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, forgive me\xe2\x80\x94let us always love each other\xe2\x80\x9d; and they clung and\r\nwept together.\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SIXTH\r\n\r\nTHE GREAT TEMPTATION.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter I.\r\n\r\nA Duet in Paradise\r\n\r\nThe well-furnished drawing-room, with the open grand piano, and the\r\npleasant outlook down a sloping garden to a boat-house by the side of\r\nthe Floss, is Mr Deane\xe2\x80\x99s. The neat little lady in mourning, whose\r\nlight-brown ringlets are falling over the coloured embroidery with\r\nwhich her fingers are busy, is of course Lucy Deane; and the fine young\r\nman who is leaning down from his chair to snap the scissors in the\r\nextremely abbreviated face of the \xe2\x80\x9cKing Charles\xe2\x80\x9d lying on the young\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s feet is no other than Mr Stephen Guest, whose diamond ring,\r\nattar of roses, and air of _nonchalant_ leisure, at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock in\r\nthe day, are the graceful and odoriferous result of the largest\r\noil-mill and the most extensive wharf in St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s. There is an apparent\r\ntriviality in the action with the scissors, but your discernment\r\nperceives at once that there is a design in it which makes it eminently\r\nworthy of a large-headed, long-limbed young man; for you see that Lucy\r\nwants the scissors, and is compelled, reluctant as she may be, to shake\r\nher ringlets back, raise her soft hazel eyes, smile playfully down on\r\nthe face that is so very nearly on a level with her knee, and holding\r\nout her little shell-pink palm, to say,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy scissors, please, if you can renounce the great pleasure of\r\npersecuting my poor Minny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe foolish scissors have slipped too far over the knuckles, it seems,\r\nand Hercules holds out his entrapped fingers hopelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfound the scissors! The oval lies the wrong way. Please draw them\r\noff for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDraw them off with your other hand,\xe2\x80\x9d says Miss Lucy, roguishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but that\xe2\x80\x99s my left hand; I\xe2\x80\x99m not left-handed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucy laughs, and the scissors are drawn off with gentle touches from\r\ntiny tips, which naturally dispose Mr Stephen for a repetition _da\r\ncapo_. Accordingly, he watches for the release of the scissors, that he\r\nmay get them into his possession again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, sticking them in her band, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall not have my\r\nscissors again,\xe2\x80\x94you have strained them already. Now don\xe2\x80\x99t set Minny\r\ngrowling again. Sit up and behave properly, and then I will tell you\r\nsome news.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, throwing himself back and hanging his\r\nright arm over the corner of his chair. He might have been sitting for\r\nhis portrait, which would have represented a rather striking young man\r\nof five-and-twenty, with a square forehead, short dark-brown hair,\r\nstanding erect, with a slight wave at the end, like a thick crop of\r\ncorn, and a half-ardent, half-sarcastic glance from under his\r\nwell-marked horizontal eyebrows. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it very important news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, very. Guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going to change Minny\xe2\x80\x99s diet, and give him three ratafias\r\nsoaked in a dessert-spoonful of cream daily?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Dr Kenn has been preaching against buckram, and you ladies\r\nhave all been sending him a roundrobin, saying, \xe2\x80\x98This is a hard\r\ndoctrine; who can bear it?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, adjusting her little mouth gravely. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nrather dull of you not to guess my news, because it is about something\r\nI mentioned to you not very long ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have mentioned many things to me not long ago. Does your\r\nfeminine tyranny require that when you say the thing you mean is one of\r\nseveral things, I should know it immediately by that mark?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know you think I am silly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you are perfectly charming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd my silliness is part of my charm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t say _that_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I know you like women to be rather insipid. Philip Wakem betrayed\r\nyou; he said so one day when you were not here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I know Phil is fierce on that point; he makes it quite a personal\r\nmatter. I think he must be love-sick for some unknown lady,\xe2\x80\x94some\r\nexalted Beatrice whom he met abroad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the by,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, pausing in her work, \xe2\x80\x9cit has just occurred to\r\nme that I never found out whether my cousin Maggie will object to see\r\nPhilip, as her brother does. Tom will not enter a room where Philip is,\r\nif he knows it; perhaps Maggie may be the same, and then we sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nable to sing our glees, shall we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! is your cousin coming to stay with you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, with a\r\nlook of slight annoyance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; that was my news, which you have forgotten. She\xe2\x80\x99s going to leave\r\nher situation, where she has been nearly two years, poor thing,\xe2\x80\x94ever\r\nsince her father\xe2\x80\x99s death; and she will stay with me a month or\r\ntwo,\xe2\x80\x94many months, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd am I bound to be pleased at that news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no, not at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, with a little air of pique. \xe2\x80\x9c_I_ am\r\npleased, but that, of course, is no reason why _you_ should be pleased.\r\nThere is no girl in the world I love so well as my cousin Maggie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will be inseparable I suppose, when she comes. There will be\r\nno possibility of a _t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate_ with you any more, unless you can\r\nfind an admirer for her, who will pair off with her occasionally. What\r\nis the ground of dislike to Philip? He might have been a resource.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a family quarrel with Philip\xe2\x80\x99s father. There were very painful\r\ncircumstances, I believe. I never quite understood them, or knew them\r\nall. My uncle Tulliver was unfortunate and lost all his property, and I\r\nthink he considered Mr Wakem was somehow the cause of it. Mr Wakem\r\nbought Dorlcote Mill, my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s old place, where he always lived. You\r\nmust remember my uncle Tulliver, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, with rather supercilious indifference. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve always\r\nknown the name, and I dare say I knew the man by sight, apart from his\r\nname. I know half the names and faces in the neighbourhood in that\r\ndetached, disjointed way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was a very hot-tempered man. I remember, when I was a little girl\r\nand used to go to see my cousins, he often frightened me by talking as\r\nif he were angry. Papa told me there was a dreadful quarrel, the very\r\nday before my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s death, between him and Mr Wakem, but it was\r\nhushed up. That was when you were in London. Papa says my uncle was\r\nquite mistaken in many ways; his mind had become embittered. But Tom\r\nand Maggie must naturally feel it very painful to be reminded of these\r\nthings. They have had so much, so very much trouble. Maggie was at\r\nschool with me six years ago, when she was fetched away because of her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s misfortunes, and she has hardly had any pleasure since, I\r\nthink. She has been in a dreary situation in a school since uncle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath, because she is determined to be independent, and not live with\r\naunt Pullet; and I could hardly wish her to come to me then, because\r\ndear mamma was ill, and everything was so sad. That is why I want her\r\nto come to me now, and have a long, long holiday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery sweet and angelic of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, looking at her with an\r\nadmiring smile; \xe2\x80\x9cand all the more so if she has the conversational\r\nqualities of her mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor aunty! You are cruel to ridicule her. She is very valuable to\r\n_me_, I know. She manages the house beautifully,\xe2\x80\x94much better than any\r\nstranger would,\xe2\x80\x94and she was a great comfort to me in mamma\xe2\x80\x99s illness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but in point of companionship one would prefer that she should be\r\nrepresented by her brandy-cherries and cream-cakes. I think with a\r\nshudder that her daughter will always be present in person, and have no\r\nagreeable proxies of that kind,\xe2\x80\x94a fat, blond girl, with round blue\r\neyes, who will stare at us silently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Lucy, laughing wickedly, and clapping her hands,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat is just my cousin Maggie. You must have seen her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed; I\xe2\x80\x99m only guessing what Mrs Tulliver\xe2\x80\x99s daughter must be;\r\nand then if she is to banish Philip, our only apology for a tenor, that\r\nwill be an additional bore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I hope that may not be. I think I will ask you to call on Philip\r\nand tell him Maggie is coming to-morrow. He is quite aware of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeeling, and always keeps out of his way; so he will understand, if you\r\ntell him, that I asked you to warn him not to come until I write to ask\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you had better write a pretty note for me to take; Phil is so\r\nsensitive, you know, the least thing might frighten him off coming at\r\nall, and we had hard work to get him. I can never induce him to come to\r\nthe park; he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like my sisters, I think. It is only your fa\xc3\xabry\r\ntouch that can lay his ruffled feathers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStephen mastered the little hand that was straying toward the table,\r\nand touched it lightly with his lips. Little Lucy felt very proud and\r\nhappy. She and Stephen were in that stage of courtship which makes the\r\nmost exquisite moment of youth, the freshest blossom-time of\r\npassion,\xe2\x80\x94when each is sure of the other\xe2\x80\x99s love, but no formal\r\ndeclaration has been made, and all is mutual divination, exalting the\r\nmost trivial word, the lightest gesture, into thrills delicate and\r\ndelicious as wafted jasmine scent. The explicitness of an engagement\r\nwears off this finest edge of susceptibility; it is jasmine gathered\r\nand presented in a large bouquet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is really odd that you should have hit so exactly on Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nappearance and manners,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cunning Lucy, moving to reach her\r\ndesk, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause she might have been like her brother, you know; and Tom\r\nhas not round eyes; and he is as far as possible from staring at\r\npeople.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I suppose he is like the father; he seems to be as proud as\r\nLucifer. Not a brilliant companion, though, I should think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like Tom. He gave me my Minny when I lost Lolo; and papa is very\r\nfond of him: he says Tom has excellent principles. It was through him\r\nthat his father was able to pay all his debts before he died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, ah; I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard about that. I heard your father and mine talking\r\nabout it a little while ago, after dinner, in one of their interminable\r\ndiscussions about business. They think of doing something for young\r\nTulliver; he saved them from a considerable loss by riding home in some\r\nmarvellous way, like Turpin, to bring them news about the stoppage of a\r\nbank, or something of that sort. But I was rather drowsy at the time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStephen rose from his seat, and sauntered to the piano, humming in\r\nfalsetto, \xe2\x80\x9cGraceful Consort,\xe2\x80\x9d as he turned over the volume of \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nCreation,\xe2\x80\x9d which stood open on the desk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and sing this,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, when he saw Lucy rising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, \xe2\x80\x98Graceful Consort\xe2\x80\x99? I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it suits your voice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind; it exactly suits my feeling, which, Philip will have it,\r\nis the grand element of good singing. I notice men with indifferent\r\nvoices are usually of that opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhilip burst into one of his invectives against \xe2\x80\x98The Creation\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nother day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, seating herself at the piano. \xe2\x80\x9cHe says it has a\r\nsort of sugared complacency and flattering make-believe in it, as if it\r\nwere written for the birthday _f\xc3\xaate_ of a German Grand-Duke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, pooh! He is the fallen Adam with a soured temper. We are Adam and\r\nEve unfallen, in Paradise. Now, then,\xe2\x80\x94the recitative, for the sake of\r\nthe moral. You will sing the whole duty of woman,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98And from obedience\r\ngrows my pride and happiness.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no, I shall not respect an Adam who drags the _tempo_, as you\r\nwill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, beginning to play the duet.\r\n\r\nSurely the only courtship unshaken by doubts and fears must be that in\r\nwhich the lovers can sing together. The sense of mutual fitness that\r\nsprings from the two deep notes fulfilling expectation just at the\r\nright moment between the notes of the silvery soprano, from the perfect\r\naccord of descending thirds and fifths, from the preconcerted loving\r\nchase of a fugue, is likely enough to supersede any immediate demand\r\nfor less impassioned forms of agreement. The contralto will not care to\r\ncatechise the bass; the tenor will foresee no embarrassing dearth of\r\nremark in evenings spent with the lovely soprano. In the provinces,\r\ntoo, where music was so scarce in that remote time, how could the\r\nmusical people avoid falling in love with each other? Even political\r\nprinciple must have been in danger of relaxation under such\r\ncircumstances; and the violin, faithful to rotten boroughs, must have\r\nbeen tempted to fraternise in a demoralizing way with a reforming\r\nvioloncello. In that case, the linnet-throated soprano and the\r\nfull-toned bass singing,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cWith thee delight is ever new,\r\n     With thee is life incessant bliss,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nbelieved what they sang all the more _because_ they sang it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow for Raphael\xe2\x80\x99s great song,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, when they had finished the\r\nduet. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do the \xe2\x80\x98heavy beasts\xe2\x80\x99 to perfection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat sounds complimentary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, looking at his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cBy\r\nJove, it\xe2\x80\x99s nearly half-past one! Well, I can just sing this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStephen delivered with admirable ease the deep notes representing the\r\ntread of the heavy beasts; but when a singer has an audience of two,\r\nthere is room for divided sentiments. Minny\xe2\x80\x99s mistress was charmed; but\r\nMinny, who had intrenched himself, trembling, in his basket as soon as\r\nthe music began, found this thunder so little to his taste that he\r\nleaped out and scampered under the remotest _chiffonnier_, as the most\r\neligible place in which a small dog could await the crack of doom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, \xe2\x80\x98graceful consort,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, buttoning his coat across\r\nwhen he had done singing, and smiling down from his tall height, with\r\nthe air of rather a patronizing lover, at the little lady on the\r\nmusic-stool. \xe2\x80\x9cMy bliss is not incessant, for I must gallop home. I\r\npromised to be there at lunch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will not be able to call on Philip, then? It is of no consequence;\r\nI have said everything in my note.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will be engaged with your cousin to-morrow, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we are going to have a little family-party. My cousin Tom will\r\ndine with us; and poor aunty will have her two children together for\r\nthe first time. It will be very pretty; I think a great deal about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I may come the next day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes! Come and be introduced to my cousin Maggie; though you can\r\nhardly be said not to have seen her, you have described her so well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, then.\xe2\x80\x9d And there was that slight pressure of the hands, and\r\nmomentary meeting of the eyes, which will often leave a little lady\r\nwith a slight flush and smile on her face that do not subside\r\nimmediately when the door is closed, and with an inclination to walk up\r\nand down the room rather than to seat herself quietly at her\r\nembroidery, or other rational and improving occupation. At least this\r\nwas the effect on Lucy; and you will not, I hope, consider it an\r\nindication of vanity predominating over more tender impulses, that she\r\njust glanced in the chimney-glass as her walk brought her near it. The\r\ndesire to know that one has not looked an absolute fright during a few\r\nhours of conversation may be construed as lying within the bounds of a\r\nlaudable benevolent consideration for others. And Lucy had so much of\r\nthis benevolence in her nature that I am inclined to think her small\r\negoisms were impregnated with it, just as there are people not\r\naltogether unknown to you whose small benevolences have a predominant\r\nand somewhat rank odor of egoism. Even now, that she is walking up and\r\ndown with a little triumphant flutter of her girlish heart at the sense\r\nthat she is loved by the person of chief consequence in her small\r\nworld, you may see in her hazel eyes an ever-present sunny benignity,\r\nin which the momentary harmless flashes of personal vanity are quite\r\nlost; and if she is happy in thinking of her lover, it is because the\r\nthought of him mingles readily with all the gentle affections and\r\ngood-natured offices with which she fills her peaceful days. Even now,\r\nher mind, with that instantaneous alternation which makes two currents\r\nof feeling or imagination seem simultaneous, is glancing continually\r\nfrom Stephen to the preparations she has only half finished in Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nroom. Cousin Maggie should be treated as well as the grandest\r\nlady-visitor,\xe2\x80\x94nay, better, for she should have Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s best prints and\r\ndrawings in her bedroom, and the very finest bouquet of spring flowers\r\non her table. Maggie would enjoy all that, she was so found of pretty\r\nthings! And there was poor aunt Tulliver, that no one made any account\r\nof, she was to be surprised with the present of a cap of superlative\r\nquality, and to have her health drunk in a gratifying manner, for which\r\nLucy was going to lay a plot with her father this evening. Clearly, she\r\nhad not time to indulge in long reveries about her own happy\r\nlove-affairs. With this thought she walked toward the door, but paused\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, then, Minny?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, stooping in answer to some\r\nwhimpering of that small quadruped, and lifting his glossy head against\r\nher pink cheek. \xe2\x80\x9cDid you think I was going without you? Come, then, let\r\nus go and see Sinbad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSinbad was Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s chestnut horse, that she always fed with her own hand\r\nwhen he was turned out in the paddock. She was fond of feeding\r\ndependent creatures, and knew the private tastes of all the animals\r\nabout the house, delighting in the little rippling sounds of her\r\ncanaries when their beaks were busy with fresh seed, and in the small\r\nnibbling pleasures of certain animals which, lest she should appear too\r\ntrivial, I will here call \xe2\x80\x9cthe more familiar rodents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWas not Stephen Guest right in his decided opinion that this slim\r\nmaiden of eighteen was quite the sort of wife a man would not be likely\r\nto repent of marrying,\xe2\x80\x94a woman who was loving and thoughtful for other\r\nwomen, not giving them Judas-kisses with eyes askance on their welcome\r\ndefects, but with real care and vision for their half-hidden pains and\r\nmortifications, with long ruminating enjoyment of little pleasures\r\nprepared for them? Perhaps the emphasis of his admiration did not fall\r\nprecisely on this rarest quality in her; perhaps he approved his own\r\nchoice of her chiefly because she did not strike him as a remarkable\r\nrarity. A man likes his wife to be pretty; well, Lucy was pretty, but\r\nnot to a maddening extent. A man likes his wife to be accomplished,\r\ngentle, affectionate, and not stupid; and Lucy had all these\r\nqualifications. Stephen was not surprised to find himself in love with\r\nher, and was conscious of excellent judgment in preferring her to Miss\r\nLeyburn, the daughter of the county member, although Lucy was only the\r\ndaughter of his father\xe2\x80\x99s subordinate partner; besides, he had had to\r\ndefy and overcome a slight unwillingness and disappointment in his\r\nfather and sisters,\xe2\x80\x94a circumstance which gives a young man an agreeable\r\nconsciousness of his own dignity. Stephen was aware that he had sense\r\nand independence enough to choose the wife who was likely to make him\r\nhappy, unbiassed by any indirect considerations. He meant to choose\r\nLucy; she was a little darling, and exactly the sort of woman he had\r\nalways admired.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter II.\r\n\r\nFirst Impressions\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very clever, Maggie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy. She was kneeling on a footstool\r\nat Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s feet, after placing that dark lady in the large\r\ncrimson-velvet chair. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel sure you will like him. I hope you will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be very difficult to please,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, smiling, and\r\nholding up one of Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s long curls, that the sunlight might shine\r\nthrough it. \xe2\x80\x9cA gentleman who thinks he is good enough for Lucy must\r\nexpect to be sharply criticised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, he\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal too good for me. And sometimes, when he is\r\naway, I almost think it can\xe2\x80\x99t really be that he loves me. But I can\r\nnever doubt it when he is with me, though I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear any one but\r\nyou to know that I feel in that way, Maggie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then, if I disapprove of him you can give him up, since you are\r\nnot engaged,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, with playful gravity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather not be engaged. When people are engaged, they begin to\r\nthink of being married soon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, too thoroughly preoccupied to\r\nnotice Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s joke; \xe2\x80\x9cand I should like everything to go on for a long\r\nwhile just as it is. Sometimes I am quite frightened lest Stephen\r\nshould say that he has spoken to papa; and from something that fell\r\nfrom papa the other day, I feel sure he and Mr Guest are expecting\r\nthat. And Stephen\xe2\x80\x99s sisters are very civil to me now. At first, I think\r\nthey didn\xe2\x80\x99t like his paying me attention; and that was natural. It\r\n_does_ seem out of keeping that I should ever live in a great place\r\nlike the Park House, such a little insignificant thing as I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut people are not expected to be large in proportion to the houses\r\nthey live in, like snails,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cPray, are Mr\r\nGuest\xe2\x80\x99s sisters giantesses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no; and not handsome,\xe2\x80\x94that is, not very,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, half-penitent\r\nat this uncharitable remark. \xe2\x80\x9cBut _he_ is\xe2\x80\x94at least he is generally\r\nconsidered very handsome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThough you are unable to share that opinion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, blushing pink over brow and neck. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\na bad plan to raise expectation; you will perhaps be disappointed. But\r\nI have prepared a charming surprise for _him;_ I shall have a glorious\r\nlaugh against him. I shall not tell you what it is, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucy rose from her knees and went to a little distance, holding her\r\npretty head on one side, as if she had been arranging Maggie for a\r\nportrait, and wished to judge of the general effect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand up a moment, Maggie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your pleasure now?\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, smiling languidly as she rose\r\nfrom her chair and looked down on her slight, aerial cousin, whose\r\nfigure was quite subordinate to her faultless drapery of silk and\r\ncrape.\r\n\r\nLucy kept her contemplative attitude a moment or two in silence, and\r\nthen said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t think what witchery it is in you, Maggie, that makes you look\r\nbest in shabby clothes; though you really must have a new dress now.\r\nBut do you know, last night I was trying to fancy you in a handsome,\r\nfashionable dress, and do what I would, that old limp merino would come\r\nback as the only right thing for you. I wonder if Marie Antoinette\r\nlooked all the grander when her gown was darned at the elbows. Now, if\r\n_I_ were to put anything shabby on, I should be quite unnoticeable. I\r\nshould be a mere rag.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, quite,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, with mock gravity. \xe2\x80\x9cYou would be liable to be\r\nswept out of the room with the cobwebs and carpet-dust, and to find\r\nyourself under the grate, like Cinderella. Mayn\xe2\x80\x99t I sit down now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, now you may,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, laughing. Then, with an air of serious\r\nreflection, unfastening her large jet brooch, \xe2\x80\x9cBut you must change\r\nbrooches, Maggie; that little butterfly looks silly on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut won\xe2\x80\x99t that mar the charming effect of my consistent shabbiness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Maggie, seating herself submissively, while Lucy knelt again and\r\nunfastened the contemptible butterfly. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish my mother were of your\r\nopinion, for she was fretting last night because this is my best frock.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve been saving my money to pay for some lessons; I shall never get a\r\nbetter situation without more accomplishments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaggie gave a little sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, don\xe2\x80\x99t put on that sad look again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, pinning the large\r\nbrooch below Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s fine throat. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re forgetting that you\xe2\x80\x99ve left\r\nthat dreary schoolroom behind you, and have no little girls\xe2\x80\x99 clothes to\r\nmend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is with me as I used to think it would be with\r\nthe poor uneasy white bear I saw at the show. I thought he must have\r\ngot so stupid with the habit of turning backward and forward in that\r\nnarrow space that he would keep doing it if they set him free. One gets\r\na bad habit of being unhappy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I shall put you under a discipline of pleasure that will make you\r\nlose that bad habit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, sticking the black butterfly absently\r\nin her own collar, while her eyes met Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s affectionately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou dear, tiny thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, in one of her bursts of loving\r\nadmiration, \xe2\x80\x9cyou enjoy other people\xe2\x80\x99s happiness so much, I believe you\r\nwould do without any of your own. I wish I were like you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve never been tried in that way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve always been so\r\nhappy. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether I could bear much trouble; I never had any\r\nbut poor mamma\xe2\x80\x99s death. You _have_ been tried, Maggie; and I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you\r\nfeel for other people quite as much as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Lucy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, shaking her head slowly, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t enjoy their\r\nhappiness as you do, else I should be more contented. I do feel for\r\nthem when they are in trouble; I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I could ever bear to make\r\nany one _un_happy; and yet I often hate myself, because I get angry\r\nsometimes at the sight of happy people. I think I get worse as I get\r\nolder, more selfish. That seems very dreadful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Maggie!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, in a tone of remonstrance, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe a\r\nword of that. It is all a gloomy fancy, just because you are depressed\r\nby a dull, wearisome life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, resolutely clearing away the clouds\r\nfrom her face with a bright smile, and throwing herself backward in her\r\nchair. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps it comes from the school diet,\xe2\x80\x94watery rice-pudding\r\nspiced with Pinnock. Let us hope it will give way before my mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncustards and this charming Geoffrey Crayon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaggie took up the \xe2\x80\x9cSketch Book,\xe2\x80\x9d which lay by her on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I look fit to be seen with this little brooch?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, going to\r\nsurvey the effect in the chimney-glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no, Mr Guest will be obliged to go out of the room again if he sees\r\nyou in it. Pray make haste and put another on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucy hurried out of the room, but Maggie did not take the opportunity\r\nof opening her book; she let it fall on her knees, while her eyes\r\nwandered to the window, where she could see the sunshine falling on the\r\nrich clumps of spring flowers and on the long hedge of laurels, and\r\nbeyond, the silvery breadth of the dear old Floss, that at this\r\ndistance seemed to be sleeping in a morning holiday. The sweet fresh\r\ngarden-scent came through the open window, and the birds were busy\r\nflitting and alighting, gurgling and singing. Yet Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s eyes began\r\nto fill with tears. The sight of the old scenes had made the rush of\r\nmemories so painful that even yesterday she had only been able to\r\nrejoice in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s restored comfort and Tom\xe2\x80\x99s brotherly\r\nfriendliness as we rejoice in good news of friends at a distance,\r\nrather than in the presence of a happiness which we share. Memory and\r\nimagination urged upon her a sense of privation too keen to let her\r\ntaste what was offered in the transient present. Her future, she\r\nthought, was likely to be worse than her past, for after her years of\r\ncontented renunciation, she had slipped back into desire and longing;\r\nshe found joyless days of distasteful occupation harder and harder; she\r\nfound the image of the intense and varied life she yearned for, and\r\ndespaired of, becoming more and more importunate. The sound of the\r\nopening door roused her, and hastily wiping away her tears, she began\r\nto turn over the leaves of her book.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is one pleasure, I know, Maggie, that your deepest dismalness\r\nwill never resist,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, beginning to speak as soon as she\r\nentered the room. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is music, and I mean you to have quite a\r\nriotous feast of it. I mean you to get up your playing again, which\r\nused to be so much better than mine, when we were at Laceham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would have laughed to see me playing the little girls\xe2\x80\x99 tunes over\r\nand over to them, when I took them to practise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, \xe2\x80\x9cjust for\r\nthe sake of fingering the dear keys again. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether I\r\ncould play anything more difficult now than \xe2\x80\x98Begone, dull care!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what a wild state of joy you used to be in when the glee-men\r\ncame round,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, taking up her embroidery; \xe2\x80\x9cand we might have\r\nall those old glees that you used to love so, if I were certain that\r\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t feel exactly as Tom does about some things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should have thought there was nothing you might be more certain of,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Maggie, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ought rather to have said, one particular thing. Because if you feel\r\njust as he does about that, we shall want our third voice. St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s is\r\nso miserably provided with musical gentlemen. There are really only\r\nStephen and Philip Wakem who have any knowledge of music, so as to be\r\nable to sing a part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucy had looked up from her work as she uttered the last sentence, and\r\nsaw that there was a change in Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes it hurt you to hear the name mentioned, Maggie? If it does, I\r\nwill not speak of him again. I know Tom will not see him if he can\r\navoid it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t feel at all as Tom does on that subject,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, rising\r\nand going to the window as if she wanted to see more of the landscape.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve always liked Philip Wakem ever since I was a little girl, and saw\r\nhim at Lorton. He was so good when Tom hurt his foot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99m so glad!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy. \xe2\x80\x9cThen you won\xe2\x80\x99t mind his coming\r\nsometimes, and we can have much more music than we could without him.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m very fond of poor Philip, only I wish he were not so morbid about\r\nhis deformity. I suppose it _is_ his deformity that makes him so sad,\r\nand sometimes bitter. It is certainly very piteous to see his poor\r\nlittle crooked body and pale face among great, strong people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Lucy\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, trying to arrest the prattling stream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, there is the door-bell. She enjoyed her\r\nlover\xe2\x80\x99s confusion; the advantage was usually on his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis designing cousin of yours quite deceived me, Miss Tulliver,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nStephen, seating himself by Lucy, and stooping to play with Minny, only\r\nlooking at Maggie furtively. \xe2\x80\x9cShe said you had light hair and blue\r\neyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, it was you who said so,\xe2\x80\x9d remonstrated Lucy. \xe2\x80\x9cI only refrained\r\nfrom destroying your confidence in your own second-sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could always err in the same way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, \xe2\x80\x9cand find\r\nreality so much more beautiful than my preconceptions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you have proved yourself equal to the occasion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nsaid what it was incumbent on you to say under the circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe flashed a slightly defiant look at him; it was clear to her that he\r\nhad been drawing a satirical portrait of her beforehand. Lucy had said\r\nhe was inclined to be satirical, and Maggie had mentally supplied the\r\naddition, \xe2\x80\x9cand rather conceited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn alarming amount of devil there,\xe2\x80\x9d was Stephen\xe2\x80\x99s first thought. The\r\nsecond, when she had bent over her work, was, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish she would look at\r\nme again.\xe2\x80\x9d The next was to answer,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose all phrases of mere compliment have their turn to be true. A\r\nman is occasionally grateful when he says \xe2\x80\x98Thank you.\xe2\x80\x99 It\xe2\x80\x99s rather hard\r\nupon him that he must use the same words with which all the world\r\ndeclines a disagreeable invitation, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so, Miss Tulliver?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, looking at him with her direct glance; \xe2\x80\x9cif we use\r\ncommon words on a great occasion, they are the more striking, because\r\nthey are felt at once to have a particular meaning, like old banners,\r\nor everyday clothes, hung up in a sacred place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen my compliment ought to be eloquent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, really not\r\nquite knowing what he said while Maggie looked at him, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing that the\r\nwords were so far beneath the occasion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo compliment can be eloquent, except as an expression of\r\nindifference,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, flushing a little.\r\n\r\nLucy was rather alarmed; she thought Stephen and Maggie were not going\r\nto like each other. She had always feared lest Maggie should appear too\r\nold and clever to please that critical gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, dear Maggie,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe interposed, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have always pretended that you are too fond of\r\nbeing admired; and now, I think, you are angry because some one\r\nventures to admire you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie; \xe2\x80\x9cI like too well to feel that I am admired,\r\nbut compliments never make me feel that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will never pay you a compliment again, Miss Tulliver,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you; that will be a proof of respect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Maggie! She was so unused to society that she could take nothing\r\nas a matter of course, and had never in her life spoken from the lips\r\nmerely, so that she must necessarily appear absurd to more experienced\r\nladies, from the excessive feeling she was apt to throw into very\r\ntrivial incidents. But she was even conscious herself of a little\r\nabsurdity in this instance. It was true she had a theoretic objection\r\nto compliments, and had once said impatiently to Philip that she didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsee why women were to be told with a simper that they were beautiful,\r\nany more than old men were to be told that they were venerable; still,\r\nto be so irritated by a common practice in the case of a stranger like\r\nMr Stephen Guest, and to care about his having spoken slightingly of\r\nher before he had seen her, was certainly unreasonable, and as soon as\r\nshe was silent she began to be ashamed of herself. It did not occur to\r\nher that her irritation was due to the pleasanter emotion which\r\npreceded it, just as when we are satisfied with a sense of glowing\r\nwarmth an innocent drop of cold water may fall upon us as a sudden\r\nsmart.\r\n\r\nStephen was too well bred not to seem unaware that the previous\r\nconversation could have been felt embarrassing, and at once began to\r\ntalk of impersonal matters, asking Lucy if she knew when the bazaar was\r\nat length to take place, so that there might be some hope of seeing her\r\nrain the influence of her eyes on objects more grateful than those\r\nworsted flowers that were growing under her fingers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome day next month, I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy. \xe2\x80\x9cBut your sisters are\r\ndoing more for it than I am; they are to have the largest stall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh yes; but they carry on their manufactures in their own\r\nsitting-room, where I don\xe2\x80\x99t intrude on them. Your\r\nexquisite sewing is quite a mystery to me, you used to dislike that\r\nsort of work so much in old days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a mystery easily explained, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, looking up\r\nquietly. \xe2\x80\x9cPlain sewing was the only thing I could get money by, so I\r\nwas obliged to try and do it well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucy, good and simple as she was, could not help blushing a little. She\r\ndid not quite like that Stephen should know that; Maggie need not have\r\nmentioned it. Perhaps there was some pride in the confession,\xe2\x80\x94the pride\r\nof poverty that will not be ashamed of itself. But if Maggie had been\r\nthe queen of coquettes she could hardly have invented a means of giving\r\ngreater piquancy to her beauty in Stephen\xe2\x80\x99s eyes; I am not sure that\r\nthe quiet admission of plain sewing and poverty would have done alone,\r\nbut assisted by the beauty, they made Maggie more unlike other women\r\neven than she had seemed at first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can knit, Lucy,\xe2\x80\x9d Maggie went on, \xe2\x80\x9cif that will be of any use for\r\nyour bazaar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, of infinite use. I shall set you to work with scarlet wool\r\nto-morrow. But your sister is the most enviable person,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nLucy, turning to Stephen, \xe2\x80\x9cto have the talent of modelling. She is\r\ndoing a wonderful bust of Dr Kenn entirely from memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, if she can remember to put the eyes very near together, and the\r\ncorners of the mouth very far apart, the likeness can hardly fail to be\r\nstriking in St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow that is very wicked of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, looking rather hurt. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t think you would speak disrespectfully of Dr Kenn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say anything disrespectful of Dr Kenn? Heaven forbid! But I am not\r\nbound to respect a libellous bust of him. I think Kenn one of the\r\nfinest fellows in the world. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care much about the tall\r\ncandlesticks he has put on the communion-table, and I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like to\r\nspoil my temper by getting up to early prayers every morning. That was a very fine thing of him,\xe2\x80\x94taking\r\ninto his house that poor lad Grattan, who shot his mother by accident.\r\nHe sacrifices more time than a less busy man could spare, to save the\r\npoor fellow from getting into a morbid state of mind about it.
