It was clear that she _must_ go on now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake my arm,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, entreatingly; and she took it, feeling all\r\nthe while as if she were sliding downward in a nightmare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no end to this misery,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, struggling to repel the\r\ninfluence by speech. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is wicked\xe2\x80\x94base\xe2\x80\x94ever allowing a word or look\r\nthat Lucy\xe2\x80\x94that others might not have seen. Think of Lucy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do think of her\xe2\x80\x94bless her. If I didn\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d Stephen had laid his hand\r\non Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s that rested on his arm, and they both felt it difficult to\r\nspeak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I have other ties,\xe2\x80\x9d Maggie went on, at last, with a desperate\r\neffort, \xe2\x80\x9ceven if Lucy did not exist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are engaged to Philip Wakem?\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI consider myself engaged to him; I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to marry any one else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStephen was silent again until they had turned out of the sun into a\r\nside lane, all grassy and sheltered. Then he burst out impetuously,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is unnatural, it is horrible. Maggie, if you loved me as I love\r\nyou, we should throw everything else to the winds for the sake of\r\nbelonging to each other. We should break all these mistaken ties that\r\nwere made in blindness, and determine to marry each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather die than fall into that temptation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie, with\r\ndeep, slow distinctness, all the gathered spiritual force of painful\r\nyears coming to her aid in this extremity. She drew her arm from his as\r\nshe spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, then, that you don\xe2\x80\x99t care for me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, almost violently.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me that you love some one else better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt darted through Maggie\xe2\x80\x99s mind that here was a mode of releasing\r\nherself from outward struggle,\xe2\x80\x94to tell Stephen that her whole heart was\r\nPhilip\xe2\x80\x99s. But her lips would not utter that, and she was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you do love me, dearest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, gently, taking her hand\r\nagain and laying it within his arm, \xe2\x80\x9cit is better\xe2\x80\x94it is right that we\r\nshould marry each other. We can\xe2\x80\x99t help the pain it will give. It is\r\ncome upon us without our seeking; it is natural; it has taken hold of\r\nme in spite of every effort I have made to resist it. God knows, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen trying to be faithful to tacit engagements, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve only made\r\nthings worse; I\xe2\x80\x99d better have given way at first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaggie was silent. If it were _not_ wrong\xe2\x80\x94if she were once convinced of\r\nthat, and need no longer beat and struggle against this current, soft\r\nand yet strong as the summer stream!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay \xe2\x80\x98yes,\xe2\x80\x99 dearest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephen, leaning to look entreatingly in her\r\nface. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat could we care about in the whole world beside, if we\r\nbelonged to each other?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer breath was on his face, his lips were very near hers, but there was\r\na great dread dwelling in his love for her.\r\n\r\nHer lips and eyelids quivered; she opened her eyes full on his for an\r\ninstant, like a lovely wild animal timid and struggling under caresses,\r\nand then turned sharp round toward home again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd after all,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, in an impatient tone, trying to defeat his\r\nown scruples as well as hers, \xe2\x80\x9cI am breaking no positive engagement; if\r\nLucy\xe2\x80\x99s affections had been withdrawn from me and given to some one\r\nelse, I should have felt no right to assert a claim on her. If you are\r\nnot absolutely pledged to Philip, we are neither of us bound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t believe that; it is not your real feeling,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maggie,\r\nearnestly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou feel, as I do, that the real tie lies in the feelings\r\nand expectations we have raised in other minds. Else all pledges might\r\nbe broken, when there was no outward penalty. There would be no such\r\nthing as faithfulness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStephen was silent; he could not pursue that argument; the opposite\r\nconviction had wrought in him too strongly through his previous time of\r\nstruggle. But it soon presented itself in a new form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe pledge _can\xe2\x80\x99t_ be fulfilled,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with impetuous insistence.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is unnatural; we can only pretend to give ourselves to any one\r\nelse. There is wrong in that too; there may be misery in it for _them_\r\nas well as for us. Maggie, you must see that; you do see that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was looking eagerly at her face for the least sign of compliance;\r\nhis large, firm, gentle grasp was on her hand. She was silent for a few\r\nmoments, with her eyes fixed on the ground; then she drew a deep\r\nbreath, and said, looking up at him with solemn sadness,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is difficult,\xe2\x80\x94life is very difficult! It seems right to me\r\nsometimes that we should follow our strongest feeling; but then, such\r\nfeelings continually come across the ties that all our former life has\r\nmade for us,\xe2\x80\x94the ties that have made others dependent on us,\xe2\x80\x94and would\r\ncut them in two. If life were quite easy and simple, as it might have\r\nbeen in Paradise, and we could always see that one being first toward\r\nwhom\xe2\x80\x94I mean, if life did not make duties for us before love comes, love\r\nwould be a sign that two people ought to belong to each other. But I\r\nsee\xe2\x80\x94I feel it is not so now; there are things we must renounce in life;\r\nsome of us must resign love. Many things are difficult and dark to me;\r\nbut I see one thing quite clearly,\xe2\x80\x94that I must not, cannot, seek my own\r\nhappiness by sacrificing others. Love is natural; but surely pity and\r\nfaithfulness and memory are natural too. And they would live in me\r\nstill, and punish me if I did not obey them. I should be haunted by the\r\nsuffering I had caused. Our love would be poisoned. Don\xe2\x80\x99t urge me; help\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x94help me, _because_ I love you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaggie had become more and more earnest as she went on; her face had\r\nbecome flushed, and her eyes fuller and fuller of appealing love.\r\nStephen had the fibre of nobleness in him that vibrated to her appeal;\r\nbut in the same moment\xe2\x80\x94how could it be otherwise?\xe2\x80\x94that pleading beauty\r\ngained new power over him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in scarcely more than a whisper, while his arm\r\nstole round her, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll do, I\xe2\x80\x99ll bear anything you wish. But\xe2\x80\x94one\r\nkiss\xe2\x80\x94one\xe2\x80\x94the last\xe2\x80\x94before we part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne kiss, and then a long look, until Maggie said tremulously, \xe2\x80\x9cLet me\r\ngo,\xe2\x80\x94let me make haste back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hurried along, and not another word was spoken. Stephen stood still\r\nand beckoned when they came within sight of Willy and the horse, and\r\nMaggie went on through the gate. Mrs Moss was standing alone at the\r\ndoor of the old porch; she had sent all the cousins in, with kind\r\nthoughtfulness. It might be a joyful thing that Maggie had a rich and\r\nhandsome lover, but she would naturally feel embarrassed at coming in\r\nagain; and it might _not_ be joyful. In either case Mrs Moss waited\r\nanxiously to receive Maggie by herself. The speaking face told plainly\r\nenough that, if there was joy, it was of a very agitating, dubious\r\nsort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down here a bit, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d She drew Maggie into the porch, and sat\r\ndown on the bench by her; there was no privacy in the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, aunt Gritty, I\xe2\x80\x99m very wretched! I wish I could have died when I\r\nwas fifteen. It seemed so easy to give things up then; it is so hard\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor child threw her arms round her aunt\xe2\x80\x99s neck, and fell into\r\nlong, deep sobs.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XII.\r\n\r\nA Family Party\r\n\r\nMaggie left her good aunt Gritty at the end of the week, and went to\r\nGarum Firs to pay her visit to aunt Pullet according to agreement. In\r\nthe mean time very unexpected things had happened, and there was to be\r\na family party at Garum to discuss and celebrate a change in the\r\nfortunes of the Tullivers, which was likely finally to carry away the\r\nshadow of their demerits like the last limb of an eclipse, and cause\r\ntheir hitherto obscured virtues to shine forth in full-rounded\r\nsplendor. It is pleasant to know that a new ministry just come into\r\noffice are not the only fellow-men who enjoy a period of high\r\nappreciation and full-blown eulogy; in many respectable families\r\nthroughout this realm, relatives becoming creditable meet with a\r\nsimilar cordiality of recognition, which in its fine freedom from the\r\ncoercion of any antecedents, suggests the hopeful possibility that we\r\nmay some day without any notice find ourselves in full millennium, with\r\ncockatrices who have ceased to bite, and wolves that no longer show\r\ntheir teeth with any but the blandest intentions.\r\n\r\nLucy came so early as to have the start even of aunt Glegg; for she\r\nlonged to have some undisturbed talk with Maggie about the wonderful\r\nnews. It seemed, did it not? said Lucy, with her prettiest air of\r\nwisdom, as if everything, even other people\xe2\x80\x99s misfortunes (poor\r\ncreatures!) were conspiring now to make poor dear aunt Tulliver, and\r\ncousin Tom, and naughty Maggie too, if she were not obstinately bent on\r\nthe contrary, as happy as they deserved to be after all their troubles.\r\nTo think that the very day\xe2\x80\x94the _very day_\xe2\x80\x94after Tom had come back from\r\nNewcastle, that unfortunate young Jetsome, whom Mr Wakem had placed at\r\nthe Mill, had been pitched off his horse in a drunken fit, and was\r\nlying at St Ogg\xe2\x80\x99s in a dangerous state, so that Wakem had signified his\r\nwish that the new purchasers should enter on the premises at once!\r\n\r\nIt was very dreadful for that unhappy young man, but it did seem as if\r\nthe misfortune had happened then, rather than at any other time, in\r\norder that cousin Tom might all the sooner have the fit reward of his\r\nexemplary conduct,\xe2\x80\x94papa thought so very highly of him. Aunt Tulliver\r\nmust certainly go to the Mill now, and keep house for Tom; that was\r\nrather a loss to Lucy in the matter of household comfort; but then, to\r\nthink of poor aunty being in her old place again, and gradually getting\r\ncomforts about her there!\r\n\r\nOn this last point Lucy had her cunning projects, and when she and\r\nMaggie had made their dangerous way down the bright stairs into the\r\nhandsome parlour, where the very sunbeams seemed cleaner than\r\nelsewhere, she directed her man\xc5\x93uvres, as any other great tactician\r\nwould have done, against the weaker side of the enemy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAunt Pullet,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, seating herself on the sofa, and caressingly\r\nadjusting that lady\xe2\x80\x99s floating cap-string, \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to make up your\r\nmind what linen and things you will give Tom toward housekeeping;\r\nbecause you are always so generous,\xe2\x80\x94you give such nice things, you\r\nknow; and if you set the example, aunt Glegg will follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat she never can, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, with unusual vigor,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t got the linen to follow suit wi\xe2\x80\x99 mine, I can tell you.\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99d niver the taste, not if she\xe2\x80\x99d spend the money. Big checks and\r\nlive things, like stags and foxes, all her table-linen is,\xe2\x80\x94not a spot\r\nnor a diamond among \xe2\x80\x99em. But it\xe2\x80\x99s poor work dividing one\xe2\x80\x99s linen before\r\none dies,\xe2\x80\x94I niver thought to ha\xe2\x80\x99 done that, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs Pullet\r\ncontinued, shaking her head and looking at her sister Tulliver, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen\r\nyou and me chose the double diamont, the first flax iver we\xe2\x80\x99d spun, and\r\nthe Lord knows where yours is gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d no choice, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure, sister,\xe2\x80\x9d said poor Mrs Tulliver, accustomed\r\nto consider herself in the light of an accused person. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure it was\r\nno wish o\xe2\x80\x99 mine, iver, as I should lie awake o\xe2\x80\x99 nights thinking o\xe2\x80\x99 my\r\nbest bleached linen all over the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake a peppermint, Mrs Tulliver,\xe2\x80\x9d said uncle Pullet, feeling that he\r\nwas offering a cheap and wholesome form of comfort, which he was\r\nrecommending by example.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but, aunt Pullet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucy, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve so much beautiful linen. And\r\nsuppose you had had daughters! Then you must have divided it when they\r\nwere married.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t say as I won\xe2\x80\x99t do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pullet, \xe2\x80\x9cfor now Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nso lucky, it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing but right his friends should look on him and\r\nhelp him. There\xe2\x80\x99s the tablecloths I bought at your sale, Bessy; it was\r\nnothing but good natur\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99 me to buy \xe2\x80\x99em, for they\xe2\x80\x99ve been lying in the\r\nchest ever since. Maggie in her crude form, with her hair down\r\nher back, and altogether in a state of dubious promise, was a most\r\nundesirable niece; but now she was capable of being at once ornamental\r\nand useful. The subject was revived in aunt and uncle Glegg\xe2\x80\x99s presence,\r\nover the tea and muffins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHegh, hegh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg, good-naturedly patting Maggie on the back,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnonsense, nonsense! Don\xe2\x80\x99t let us hear of you taking a place again,\r\nMaggie. Why, you must ha\xe2\x80\x99 picked up half-a-dozen sweethearts at the\r\nbazaar; isn\xe2\x80\x99t there one of \xe2\x80\x99em the right sort of article? Come, now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Glegg,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife, with that shade of increased politeness in\r\nher severity which she always put on with her crisper fronts, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nexcuse me, but you\xe2\x80\x99re far too light for a man of your years. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I thought I should be struck\r\nwith death when you took me in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there is Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Lucy, clapping her hands. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s come on\r\nSindbad, as I told him. I was afraid he was not going to keep his\r\npromise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaggie jumped up to kiss Tom as he entered, with strong feeling, at\r\nthis first meeting since the prospect of returning to the Mill had been\r\nopened to him; and she kept his hand, leading him to the chair by her\r\nside. He smiled at\r\nher very kindly this evening, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Magsie, how\xe2\x80\x99s aunt\r\nMoss?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Glegg putting out his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nsuch a big man, you carry all before you, it, seems. You\xe2\x80\x99ll get the Mill all for your own again some\r\nday, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound. You won\xe2\x80\x99t stop half-way up the hill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I hope he\xe2\x80\x99ll bear in mind as it\xe2\x80\x99s his mother\xe2\x80\x99s family as he owes\r\nit to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Glegg. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t had them to take after, he\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbeen poorly off. There was never any failures, nor lawing, nor\r\nwastefulness in our family, nor dying without wills\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nor sudden deaths,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunt Pullet; \xe2\x80\x9callays the doctor called\r\nin. But Tom had the Dodson skin; I said that from the first. And I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know what _you_ mean to do, sister Glegg, but I mean to give him\r\na tablecloth of all my three biggest sizes but one, besides sheets. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t say what more I shall do; but _that_ I shall do, and if I should\r\ndie to-morrow, Mr Pullet, you\xe2\x80\x99ll bear it in mind,\xe2\x80\x94though you\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nblundering with the keys, and never remember as that on the third shelf\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the left-hand wardrobe, behind the night-caps with the broad\r\nties,\xe2\x80\x94not the narrow-frilled uns,\xe2\x80\x94is the key of the drawer in the Blue\r\nRoom, where the key o\xe2\x80\x99 the Blue Closet is.
